description: Excel 2016 is the powerful spreadsheet application in the Office suite. It seems every organization, large and small, uses Excel to organize and analyze data. However, many users are intimidated by Excel and confused by how it behaves as an application. The Excel 2016 Essentials for Mac series strives to empower users by learning the foundations to conquer this program. We begin with basic skills such as navigating the interface, identifying items in a spreadsheet, selecting cells, and inputting data. The series also covers formatting text and numbers, modifying a worksheet layout, printing and page layout, and managing worksheets in a workbook. While this series is designed for beginner users, it has lots of great tips and tricks for experienced users as well.

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne cover the basics of working with Excel in the Macintosh operating system. They review foundational skills and items such as starting Excel, the title bar, minimize and maximize, full screen mode, create a blank workbook, open an existing workbook, save vs. save as, and keyboard shortcuts.
episodes.title: Excel Basics

00:17:31.890 --> 00:17:34.760

322
00:17:34.760 --> 00:17:37.710
This guy right here is

00:17:37.710 --> 00:17:42.350
The name box is going to give you the name
of the cell that you are currently

324
00:17:42.350 --> 00:17:43.730

For example, if I click right here, notice

00:17:50.151 --> 00:17:52.590

a little different.

look like cell references,

330
00:18:00.602 --> 00:18:02.945

00:18:02.945 --> 00:18:06.959
And a cell reference is just the reference

332
00:18:06.959 --> 00:18:07.659

Right next to it, this big, long line over

334
00:18:11.854 --> 00:18:17.993
The formula bar is going to display the
items that you have in the active cell.

335
00:18:17.993 --> 00:18:19.993

00:18:33.710 --> 00:18:38.380

because it's the result of

341
00:18:38.380 --> 00:18:41.620

00:23:11.853 --> 00:23:18.922

You know that the ribbon has group names.

460
00:24:48.752 --> 00:24:49.924
You know where to find them.

461
00:24:49.924 --> 00:24:53.980
The Quick Access Toolbar, the title bar,
the status bar, the name box,

462
00:24:53.980 --> 00:24:54.968
the formula bar.

463
00:24:54.968 --> 00:24:59.494
And, yeah, I think that's about
it [LAUGH] for our interface so.

464
00:24:59.494 --> 00:25:03.269
>> Well, Vonne, you have definitely given
us a map to navigate the labyrinth that is

465
00:25:03.269 --> 00:25:05.694
Excel, and
hopefully not encounter the Minotaur.

466
00:25:05.694 --> 00:25:07.346
>> [LAUGH]
>> So thank you so much for that.

467
00:25:07.346 --> 00:25:11.039
Well, I know we got more Excel coming
back at you, so definitely stay tuned.

468
00:25:11.039 --> 00:25:12.615
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

469
00:25:12.615 --> 00:25:15.406
So signing off for OfficeProTV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

470
00:25:15.406 --> 00:25:16.244
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

471
00:25:16.244 --> 00:25:17.207
>> And we'll see you next time.

472
00:25:17.207 --> 00:25:22.343
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Justin and Vonne demonstrate how to navigate a workbook . They will explain the different mouse cursors icons, scrolling, keyboard navigation, navigating with the name box, zooming, and choosing worksheets.
episodes.title: Navigate a Workbook
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.658 --> 00:00:15.860
Greetings everyone, and welcome back to
another exciting episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:15.860 --> 00:00:17.472
I'm your host Justin Dennison, and

4
00:00:17.472 --> 00:00:20.697
we're continuing on with our Excel
2016 Essentials for Mac series.

5
00:00:20.697 --> 00:00:23.192
And well, we're gonna be looking
at navigating a workbook.

6
00:00:23.192 --> 00:00:27.310
And we have our very own navigator in
the studio today with us, Ms. Vonne Smith.

7
00:00:27.310 --> 00:00:27.950
How are you doing today, Vonne?

8
00:00:27.950 --> 00:00:28.933
>> I'm doing fantastic.

9
00:00:28.933 --> 00:00:29.694
How are you doing?

10
00:00:29.694 --> 00:00:31.525
>> I am doing great as well.

11
00:00:31.525 --> 00:00:35.629
And well, we've seen over the last couple
of episodes that it's very important to be

12
00:00:35.629 --> 00:00:38.821
familiar with maybe even things
that you're like, yeah, well,

13
00:00:38.821 --> 00:00:40.261
I already know how to do that.

14
00:00:40.261 --> 00:00:41.968
But you've shown me a couple of tricks and
well,

15
00:00:41.968 --> 00:00:43.810
what kind of tricks do you
have up your sleeve now.

16
00:00:43.810 --> 00:00:45.471
>> It's a great point.

17
00:00:45.471 --> 00:00:50.915
it seems so basic or like the introductory
chapter that everybody skips over.

18
00:00:50.915 --> 00:00:54.345
But this is an important part of
just learning how to get around.

19
00:00:54.345 --> 00:00:59.457
Getting around within our workbook,
within our file, and how to select cells.

20
00:00:59.457 --> 00:01:04.977
And we're gonna go over some things
that seem very, let's say small,

21
00:01:04.977 --> 00:01:09.950
but also very like apparent, but
so many people skip over this.

22
00:01:09.950 --> 00:01:12.660
And I've watched people
struggle with this, so

23
00:01:12.660 --> 00:01:15.190
we're gonna take it slow,
we're gonna take it step by step.

24
00:01:15.190 --> 00:01:21.230
And hopefully get all the things you need
know to get around within a workbook.

25
00:01:21.230 --> 00:01:24.979
So why don't we go ahead and
get started, let's jump on down.

26
00:01:24.979 --> 00:01:27.799
And I've got my desktop,
and we're ready to go.

27
00:01:27.799 --> 00:01:30.073
So we're gonna open up a file, so

28
00:01:30.073 --> 00:01:34.804
I'm gonna go to the folder that has
the file and that is the wrong one.

29
00:01:34.804 --> 00:01:37.757
Those are my episode notes in
case you're ever wondering,

30
00:01:37.757 --> 00:01:40.490
those are the files I use for
my mark down files.

31
00:01:40.490 --> 00:01:42.700
Let's close that one and go over here.

32
00:01:42.700 --> 00:01:47.368
There we go, and we're going to
open up navigate a workbook.

33
00:01:47.368 --> 00:01:49.607
Yup, that's the name of our file.

34
00:01:49.607 --> 00:01:51.752
So we've got this.

35
00:01:51.752 --> 00:01:56.812
Before we get moving around within
the workbook or the worksheets,

36
00:01:56.812 --> 00:02:02.331
let's start off with what we're
actually looking at right now our view.

37
00:02:02.331 --> 00:02:05.273
Right now we are in the normal view.

38
00:02:05.273 --> 00:02:07.786
And as soon as I say that I'm like
I think that's the name of it.

39
00:02:07.786 --> 00:02:08.585
Why don't we check out?

40
00:02:08.585 --> 00:02:12.197
Let's go over to the view tab,
and yes, it's normal.

41
00:02:12.197 --> 00:02:15.178
I was making sure like, yes,
it's a normal in Excel.

42
00:02:15.178 --> 00:02:19.216
I think it's like print preview, maybe
it's normal in Word, I can't remember, but

43
00:02:19.216 --> 00:02:19.945
that's okay.

44
00:02:19.945 --> 00:02:21.715
[LAUGH]
>> It's one of those things as soon as you

45
00:02:21.715 --> 00:02:24.721
say it out loud, your mind immediately
goes, no, that's not right.

46
00:02:24.721 --> 00:02:25.449
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.
>> That's not right.

47
00:02:25.449 --> 00:02:27.080
So you start second guessing yourself.

48
00:02:27.080 --> 00:02:29.470
But when in doubt, check it out, right?

49
00:02:29.470 --> 00:02:30.606
So that's what you should do.

50
00:02:30.606 --> 00:02:32.548
>> Look at that, and
you rhymed right there.

51
00:02:32.548 --> 00:02:33.093
Good job.

52
00:02:33.093 --> 00:02:36.615
[LAUGH] Yes,
we are in our normal view of our workbook,

53
00:02:36.615 --> 00:02:42.100
or really right now, our work sheet,
cuz that's what we're looking at.

54
00:02:42.100 --> 00:02:47.260
So over here on the view tab you can see
that I've got some other ones in here.

55
00:02:47.260 --> 00:02:53.180
We've got normal page break preview,
we have page layout, and the custom views.

56
00:02:53.180 --> 00:02:59.330
I pretty much always 98% of the time,
I'm in the normal view.

57
00:02:59.330 --> 00:03:06.030
I do like to this particular view when I
am needing to change my page breaks of

58
00:03:06.030 --> 00:03:10.830
when I need the next page to be printed,
and where I want those breaks to happen.

59
00:03:10.830 --> 00:03:14.530
We'll talk all about that in some future
episodes, but just gonna throw it out

60
00:03:14.530 --> 00:03:17.180
there right now in case you're like,
I don't know what's going on right now.

61
00:03:17.180 --> 00:03:20.180
Let's click on it and see what happens,
and this is what you see.

62
00:03:20.180 --> 00:03:25.830
You can see where you have the divisions
as to where are your page ones and

63
00:03:25.830 --> 00:03:26.520
twos, and threes?

64
00:03:26.520 --> 00:03:31.130
And notice that it's actually
going down and then up.

65
00:03:31.130 --> 00:03:34.576
All of these can be configured
in your print settings.

66
00:03:34.576 --> 00:03:37.010
Like, which way do you wanna
go across versus down?

67
00:03:37.010 --> 00:03:40.854
And that's because I've got a lot
of information on this particular

68
00:03:40.854 --> 00:03:44.980
worksheet to kind of help us
get familiar with navigating.

69
00:03:44.980 --> 00:03:47.540
And that's why you don't
see it going across.

70
00:03:47.540 --> 00:03:49.980
You're seeing it going down first.

71
00:03:49.980 --> 00:03:53.800
And so, it's showing me where
the breaks are going to happen.

72
00:03:53.800 --> 00:03:56.936
So in case you're ever wondering
if you've got these blue lines.

73
00:03:56.936 --> 00:04:01.188
And sometimes it's even more zoomed out
depending on what type of information or

74
00:04:01.188 --> 00:04:03.388
how much information you have on a sheet.

75
00:04:03.388 --> 00:04:07.086
So this can vary from time to time.

76
00:04:07.086 --> 00:04:10.118
And then,
the other one is the page layout view.

77
00:04:10.118 --> 00:04:13.334
This is kind of like kind
of like the word view.

78
00:04:13.334 --> 00:04:18.300
[LAUGH] I see Justin's face over there
going, yeah, I feel the same way.

79
00:04:18.300 --> 00:04:19.930
I don't like this view.

80
00:04:19.930 --> 00:04:22.320
This is-
>> It doesn't seem intuitive to me,

81
00:04:22.320 --> 00:04:24.260
in the context of Excel.

82
00:04:24.260 --> 00:04:27.370
It seems like,
like this is just an add-on.

83
00:04:27.370 --> 00:04:30.552
The one place where you may
get some value out of this,

84
00:04:30.552 --> 00:04:34.959
is I wanna check to see what it will
look like if I change no print settings.

85
00:04:34.959 --> 00:04:36.193
Because if I'm not mistaken,

86
00:04:36.193 --> 00:04:39.096
this is what I'm going to get if I
just print this workbook as is, right?

87
00:04:39.096 --> 00:04:39.957
>> Yes.

88
00:04:39.957 --> 00:04:42.776
Yeah, and it is a much more visual
representation than the page

89
00:04:42.776 --> 00:04:43.900
break preview.

90
00:04:43.900 --> 00:04:48.010
You're seeing the margins and
all those things, and the header areas.

91
00:04:48.010 --> 00:04:51.560
So yeah, this is Word to me,
this isn't Excel.

92
00:04:51.560 --> 00:04:54.610
So that's why I don't like
to personally work in it.

93
00:04:54.610 --> 00:04:58.100
But it's good for you to know in case
like, hey, this is what it looks like,

94
00:04:58.100 --> 00:04:59.110
where am I?

95
00:04:59.110 --> 00:05:02.590
Always go to the View tab,
check out the buttons at the top, and

96
00:05:02.590 --> 00:05:04.580
switch yourself back into normal view.

97
00:05:04.580 --> 00:05:08.590
Behind my head, down the status bar,
there are a couple ones down here.

98
00:05:08.590 --> 00:05:10.140
You can see those buttons,

99
00:05:10.140 --> 00:05:13.230
those were the ones that were
corresponding to our different views.

100
00:05:13.230 --> 00:05:19.200
So that's another place that you can get
to the different views of your workbook.

101
00:05:19.200 --> 00:05:20.650
So check that out.

102
00:05:20.650 --> 00:05:25.265
So other things while I'm on this View
tab that we should just take notice of,

103
00:05:25.265 --> 00:05:30.306
that I believe we've already covered in
the interface episode was the formula bar,

104
00:05:30.306 --> 00:05:31.980
making sure you can see it.

105
00:05:31.980 --> 00:05:33.460
That's why they call it a view tab.

106
00:05:34.610 --> 00:05:36.550
Making sure you can see
your grid lines too.

107
00:05:36.550 --> 00:05:39.650
Because in Excel,
we're using a spreadsheet application,

108
00:05:39.650 --> 00:05:41.350
you're gonna see rows and columns.

109
00:05:41.350 --> 00:05:43.712
And these gray lines,
that's another thing.

110
00:05:43.712 --> 00:05:45.805
They don't print these gray lines,
do they?

111
00:05:45.805 --> 00:05:48.643
No, so those are known as grid lines.

112
00:05:48.643 --> 00:05:51.638
And if you turn them off,
you don't see them anymore.

113
00:05:51.638 --> 00:05:56.580
And I've seen people going, like,
it's broken, I don't see the lines.

114
00:05:56.580 --> 00:05:57.670
I'm like, you mean the borders?

115
00:05:57.670 --> 00:05:59.356
No, I just don't see it.

116
00:05:59.356 --> 00:06:01.713
You mean on the screen,
check your view tab.

117
00:06:01.713 --> 00:06:03.680
And they're like, that's it.

118
00:06:03.680 --> 00:06:05.140
So that can throw people off too.

119
00:06:06.420 --> 00:06:08.150
So different things to
watch on your View tab.

120
00:06:09.280 --> 00:06:12.460
The next thing would be your zoom level.

121
00:06:12.460 --> 00:06:13.930
What can I see right now?

122
00:06:13.930 --> 00:06:19.700
And you can control a lot of that
right here from your view tab.

123
00:06:19.700 --> 00:06:24.100
I'm zoomed in a decent amount, so
we can see the text on the page.

124
00:06:24.100 --> 00:06:29.776
But if you drop this down, and maybe I
go to say a 100% and then you go to 50%.

125
00:06:29.776 --> 00:06:31.780
Okay, I can't see that, I don't know.

126
00:06:31.780 --> 00:06:34.520
But you can see I got a lot of
information is going way out here.

127
00:06:34.520 --> 00:06:38.006
It's very blurry, I understand,
I can't even see that either.

128
00:06:38.006 --> 00:06:39.337
But you can go ahead and

129
00:06:39.337 --> 00:06:44.257
use this view tab in this drop down to go
whatever zoom magnification that you want.

130
00:06:44.257 --> 00:06:48.810
There's also a button that goes to
kind of like a 1 to 1 ratio, a 100%.

131
00:06:48.810 --> 00:06:52.800
And that's where you can zoom out there.

132
00:06:52.800 --> 00:06:57.975
I don't tend to do my zooms through
the View tab on the ribbon.

133
00:06:57.975 --> 00:07:01.483
I always actually use a shortcut,
which I'll show you.

134
00:07:01.483 --> 00:07:07.199
But again, behind my head you can
see down in that status bar you have

135
00:07:07.199 --> 00:07:14.035
your zoom slider, right here, to where if
I drag it left it's going to zoom out.

136
00:07:14.035 --> 00:07:18.372
And then going to the right
it's going to zoom in, so

137
00:07:18.372 --> 00:07:21.340
I can see, now that's pretty big.

138
00:07:21.340 --> 00:07:24.820
I'm also zoomed into
the screen magnification.

139
00:07:24.820 --> 00:07:27.380
So that's okay, I can see my text.

140
00:07:27.380 --> 00:07:31.899
You can also click the little buttons,
the little plus and minus to the left and

141
00:07:31.899 --> 00:07:35.756
right a bit if you wanted to click,
click, click, versus slide.

142
00:07:35.756 --> 00:07:41.631
And you also have a little percentage
right down here that when you click on it,

143
00:07:41.631 --> 00:07:46.261
it brings up a dialogue box to
where you can choose a particular

144
00:07:46.261 --> 00:07:47.968
zoom magnification.

145
00:07:47.968 --> 00:07:53.743
So I have to say my eyes are getting
a little older there Justin, and.

146
00:07:53.743 --> 00:07:57.588
These studio lights are quite
bright [LAUGH] and so

147
00:07:57.588 --> 00:08:01.670
our eyes get a little
older as we get older.

148
00:08:01.670 --> 00:08:03.385
>> Well-
>> Wow, I'm just talking in circles now.

149
00:08:03.385 --> 00:08:07.650
>> Vonne, I will say you don't have to
necessarily have trouble with vision.

150
00:08:07.650 --> 00:08:08.700
I'm not trying to brag,

151
00:08:08.700 --> 00:08:12.960
my vision is all right, I'm still
a little short in the tooth, so to speak.

152
00:08:12.960 --> 00:08:16.570
But I tend to run very large text sizes
in general because we stare at a computer

153
00:08:16.570 --> 00:08:18.110
screen a great deal, right?

154
00:08:18.110 --> 00:08:21.390
So if you don't need to look at
a whole lot of real estate I

155
00:08:21.390 --> 00:08:25.010
would zoom that up anyway,
which actually brings me to my question.

156
00:08:25.010 --> 00:08:26.840
When you click those plus and

157
00:08:26.840 --> 00:08:30.510
minus buttons are we
incrementing by 10% by default?

158
00:08:30.510 --> 00:08:36.040
Or does it just increment when you zoom up
and down using the plus and minus buttons?

159
00:08:36.040 --> 00:08:36.924
>> You know what?

160
00:08:36.924 --> 00:08:39.210
That's a good point.

161
00:08:39.210 --> 00:08:42.565
Look, it does look like it's
I've never noticed that.

162
00:08:42.565 --> 00:08:44.280
[LAUGH] Yeah, you know what?

163
00:08:44.280 --> 00:08:47.620
It looks like it's going
in 10% increments.

164
00:08:47.620 --> 00:08:48.975
Good to know, yes it does.

165
00:08:48.975 --> 00:08:53.070
[LAUGH] Or at least it is today,
at this point and time,

166
00:08:53.070 --> 00:08:58.355
while we're on this taping of the show so,
good to know, all right.

167
00:08:58.355 --> 00:09:01.450
So, I tend to like my shortcuts
when it comes to my zoom.

168
00:09:02.820 --> 00:09:07.449
In a PC world, if you do Ctrl scroll,
like if you have a mouse,

169
00:09:07.449 --> 00:09:09.686
I always have a mouse, okay?

170
00:09:09.686 --> 00:09:14.360
I can't only operate on a touch pad,
I just am.

171
00:09:14.360 --> 00:09:16.754
And maybe it's because I'm
more of a designer and

172
00:09:16.754 --> 00:09:19.210
I have to do a lot of work with the mouse.

173
00:09:19.210 --> 00:09:21.560
Now, in a Mac, if you want to,

174
00:09:21.560 --> 00:09:26.450
it's not just control,
it's Cmd Ctrl, those two keys.

175
00:09:26.450 --> 00:09:29.220
If you hold those two keys
down on your keyboard and

176
00:09:29.220 --> 00:09:34.520
then scrolly wheel up or
scrolly wheel down.

177
00:09:34.520 --> 00:09:40.050
You see how to move it over here,
I am zooming out and zooming in.

178
00:09:40.050 --> 00:09:42.728
It might have to do with
your mouse gestures too.

179
00:09:42.728 --> 00:09:44.296
I got really far, gosh I'm at 10%.

180
00:09:44.296 --> 00:09:46.180
Okay, let's go ahead.

181
00:09:46.180 --> 00:09:50.710
It's a little backwards because
I'm scrolling down to zoom in.

182
00:09:50.710 --> 00:09:55.110
In PC world you have to
scroll up to zoom out.

183
00:09:55.110 --> 00:09:58.150
Basically just hold those two keys,
scroll down, scroll up and

184
00:09:58.150 --> 00:09:59.070
figure out which one it is.

185
00:09:59.070 --> 00:10:00.420
And then move from there.

186
00:10:00.420 --> 00:10:01.900
>> Now, Vonne, a quick followup question.

187
00:10:01.900 --> 00:10:06.290
I know Mac can, cuz you and I actually
disagree on this about our respective

188
00:10:06.290 --> 00:10:10.390
direction that is up and
down, so to speak.

189
00:10:10.390 --> 00:10:11.790
Does this affect that?

190
00:10:11.790 --> 00:10:13.390
>> I'm going to say [LAUGH].

191
00:10:13.390 --> 00:10:15.368
You got so choked up on that question,
didn't you.

192
00:10:15.368 --> 00:10:16.210
>> I did, I did.

193
00:10:16.210 --> 00:10:17.005
I'm excited.

194
00:10:17.005 --> 00:10:21.150
>> [LAUGH] I'm going to say,
tentatively, yes.

195
00:10:22.220 --> 00:10:25.100
I'm assuming that that is,
you would have to check.

196
00:10:25.100 --> 00:10:26.850
We would need to go into our settings.

197
00:10:26.850 --> 00:10:29.560
Yeah, the natural gestures versus.

198
00:10:29.560 --> 00:10:33.910
I'm always backwards, considered,
my husband gets on me too, and

199
00:10:33.910 --> 00:10:35.560
I get on his computer and
I'm like this is all wrong.

200
00:10:35.560 --> 00:10:37.950
He's like no,
yours is the one that's wrong.

201
00:10:37.950 --> 00:10:39.390
You know what?

202
00:10:39.390 --> 00:10:40.880
I think it has something to do with it.

203
00:10:40.880 --> 00:10:46.470
So double check that, maybe I just
like being backwards, what can I say?

204
00:10:46.470 --> 00:10:48.068
But I do like that shortcut, it's fun.

205
00:10:48.068 --> 00:10:52.165
Ctrl and Cmd, and then scrolly wheel up,
scrolly wheel down.

206
00:10:52.165 --> 00:10:55.490
Talking about that scroll
since I'm already.

207
00:10:55.490 --> 00:10:59.330
By the way, I have a magic mouse
because I love the magic mouse.

208
00:10:59.330 --> 00:11:03.200
I'm an Apple girl through and through, I
pretty much have every product they have.

209
00:11:03.200 --> 00:11:10.610
So, with the magic mouse, I do have
both vertical and horizontal scrolling,

210
00:11:10.610 --> 00:11:16.710
on my mouse gestures that I have,
so I can actually go diagonal too.

211

That's where it's gonna

Let's come over here, right here.

Control, sorry,
Command right arrow takes me to the end or

00:25:07.655 --> 00:25:10.850

00:25:10.850 --> 00:25:12.451
Down arrow to get me here.

00:25:12.451 --> 00:25:19.663
So, Command right, now, if I do

00:25:19.663 --> 00:25:23.704

00:25:23.704 --> 00:25:27.506

If I'm in a specific data range,

465
00:25:33.136 --> 00:25:39.748
Command right arrow,
Command right arrow again, where am I?

466
00:25:39.748 --> 00:25:42.370
I am in column XFV.

467
00:25:44.760 --> 00:25:51.082
If I do Command down, it's gonna be

468
00:25:51.082 --> 00:25:55.822
I'm at the very last
corner of this Worksheet,

469
00:25:55.822 --> 00:25:59.290

470
00:25:59.290 --> 00:26:02.852
So, you see how it goes

471
00:26:02.852 --> 00:26:08.560
And then, you can go all to

00:26:08.560 --> 00:26:12.580
By your Command and your right and

00:26:12.580 --> 00:26:15.453

00:26:16.129 --> 00:26:19.960
It's essentially going to the bounding

476
00:26:19.960 --> 00:26:22.800
So, if you're in a data range,
Contiguous Range,

00:26:22.800 --> 00:26:25.135

areas of that range.

478
00:26:25.135 --> 00:26:29.282
You're outside, then we just kinda

479
00:26:29.282 --> 00:26:29.914

480
00:26:29.914 --> 00:26:30.754

481
00:26:30.754 --> 00:26:32.138

482
00:26:32.138 --> 00:26:36.038

00:26:36.038 --> 00:26:36.555

that's important distinction to make.

But there is another way that

00:27:05.518 --> 00:27:07.630

00:27:07.630 --> 00:27:09.466
Do you remember what this

496
00:27:09.466 --> 00:27:11.441
Well, look at that I covered,

00:27:11.441 --> 00:27:13.411
[LAUGH]
>> Can I still answer anyway?

498

>> It's called the name box?

499
00:27:15.147 --> 00:27:15.730
>> Yeah [LAUGH].

500
00:27:15.730 --> 00:27:19.208
>> All right, I mean,
I am five for five today.

501
00:27:19.208 --> 00:27:20.470
>> Gave away the answer.

502
00:27:20.470 --> 00:27:22.011
So, this is the Name Box and

503
00:27:22.011 --> 00:27:26.714
this is where it's gonna show you where is
cutting off maybe a little bit off there.

504
00:27:26.714 --> 00:27:31.090
But, it's showing you where, there we go,
I just move the mouse over [LAUGH].

505
00:27:31.090 --> 00:27:36.235
Of what cell you're in, but
you can also use that to navigate.

506
00:27:36.235 --> 00:27:41.213
If I have her up here, noticed how it

507
00:27:41.213 --> 00:27:46.187
And if I type in A1,
doesn't matter if it is capitalized,

508
00:27:46.187 --> 00:27:50.040
and I hit enter, it takes me back to A1.

509
00:27:50.040 --> 00:27:55.592
So you can use the Name Box to navigate,
i tend to not, honestly, I just don't.

510
00:27:55.592 --> 00:27:59.330
I have other shortcuts, especially if
I am using my keyboard and everything.

511
00:27:59.330 --> 00:28:03.042
And then, these little drop down arrows,
these are like, what are these?

512
00:28:03.042 --> 00:28:05.302
These are named ranges.

513
00:28:05.302 --> 00:28:07.900
You can, it's kinda like
giving it a nickname, okay.

514
00:28:07.900 --> 00:28:09.730
And you can use it to navigate.

515
00:28:09.730 --> 00:28:12.904
If I click on meow, okay,
ooh, where did it take me?

516
00:28:12.904 --> 00:28:14.200
Let me scroll out so you can see.

517
00:28:14.200 --> 00:28:18.874
It actually took me to this particular

00:28:18.874 --> 00:28:19.754

00:28:19.754 --> 00:28:21.860
And it's also on worksheet five.

00:28:21.860 --> 00:28:25.029
If I drop this down and

521
00:28:25.029 --> 00:28:31.025
Well that's a named range of cells

522
00:28:31.025 --> 00:28:36.328
So you can use named ranges in formulas,
ways to just give a nickname to places.

523
00:28:36.328 --> 00:28:40.053
I'll show you,
there's actually in our Functions, so

00:28:40.053 --> 00:28:43.010
we talk about that and
how you use a formulas.

525
00:28:43.010 --> 00:28:46.145
And l believe in advanced series where we
actually talked about naming ranges, but

526
00:28:46.145 --> 00:28:47.324
just wanna point that one out.

527
00:28:47.324 --> 00:28:50.984
>> So now, we're getting name ranges
with the Name Box absolutely within

528
00:28:50.984 --> 00:28:52.030
the work book.

529
00:28:52.030 --> 00:28:55.570
Regardless of the sheets, so
you may have a whole list of those.

530
00:28:55.570 --> 00:28:58.200
But then, maybe on different sheets and
you kinda bounce around, right?

531
00:28:58.200 --> 00:29:02.307
>> Correct yes, and
you do name it by the range of cells and

532
00:29:02.307 --> 00:29:07.415
the worksheet that it is on in
that particular workbook, correct.

533
00:29:07.415 --> 00:29:11.694
And that being said, if I needed
to navigate around my worksheets,

534
00:29:11.694 --> 00:29:14.485
down here, how do you think you do it?

535
00:29:14.485 --> 00:29:17.274
>> Well, I would probably just click on
them until with reckless abandon, and

00:29:17.274 --> 00:29:18.246

537
00:29:18.246 --> 00:29:24.075
>> [LAUGH] Yes, click Reckless Abandon

538
00:29:24.075 --> 00:29:29.609
Single click Navigate To, double click,
actually gives you a shortcut to Rename.

539
00:29:29.609 --> 00:29:33.366
Which is nice, if you wanna rename your
sheets and people are like [NOISE],

540
00:29:33.366 --> 00:29:34.830
okay and then you click off.

541
00:29:34.830 --> 00:29:37.090
But anyway, double clicking will Rename or

542
00:29:37.090 --> 00:29:41.871
Give you the option to name
your worksheets while on here,

543
00:29:41.871 --> 00:29:46.663
in your full keyboard,
if you have a page up and page down.

00:29:46.663 --> 00:29:51.136
If you use your control, not command,
cuz I just tried it with a command and

00:29:51.136 --> 00:29:53.490
it doesn't work, Control Page down.

00:29:53.490 --> 00:30:00.560
Look at my worksheet tabs, five, six,

So you can switch back and forth from

548
00:30:05.098 --> 00:30:08.373
Well, you should have
a Control Key on that keyboard and

00:30:08.373 --> 00:30:10.225
you have the page up on there.

550
00:30:10.225 --> 00:30:12.481
So that takes me to the end.

551
00:30:12.481 --> 00:30:17.023
I'm gonna do one quick one, even though
this gets into when we do our data entry,

00:30:17.023 --> 00:30:18.127

00:30:18.127 --> 00:30:23.400
Is how you can use your tab key,

554
00:30:23.400 --> 00:30:26.772
Those one thing that I didn't do and
I use this all the time.

555
00:30:26.772 --> 00:30:29.550
So, I'm here on this particular cell.

556
00:30:30.610 --> 00:30:36.167
Hitting the Tab key on the keyboard
will take you one cell to the right.

557
00:30:36.167 --> 00:30:38.155
Do you know how to go to
the left with a Tab key?

558
00:30:38.155 --> 00:30:38.823
>> Shift+tab.

559
00:30:38.823 --> 00:30:40.175
>> You are correct, my gosh.

560
00:30:40.175 --> 00:30:43.480
>> Man, I am gonna get a pay
raise after this episode.

00:30:43.480 --> 00:30:45.230
>> You also saw it in the notes,

562
00:30:45.230 --> 00:30:45.876

563
00:30:45.876 --> 00:30:51.030
>> [LAUGH] So shift tab,
hold the Shift key and click the Tab key.

564
00:30:51.030 --> 00:30:53.048
That will take you to the left.

565
00:30:53.048 --> 00:30:56.260
Now the, I'm clicking with my mouse.

566
00:30:56.260 --> 00:30:59.981
The enter key on your keyboard
takes you down, okay?

567
00:30:59.981 --> 00:31:04.077
Just goes down, Shift Enter takes you up.

568
00:31:04.077 --> 00:31:05.942
But, how do you use those in succession?

569
00:31:05.942 --> 00:31:08.040
I am using my mouse now and
I am clicking here.

570
00:31:08.040 --> 00:31:12.015
Watch, if I, okay, where am, G10, right?

571
00:31:12.015 --> 00:31:16.152
Tab, Tab, Tab, now I'm gonna Enter,

572
00:31:16.152 --> 00:31:19.696
it's like a carriage term [LAUGH].

573
00:31:19.696 --> 00:31:21.492
>> Ahh, that was unexpected,
Vaughan, you caught me with that, or

574
00:31:21.492 --> 00:31:23.370
should I have asked that question
cuz I would have gotten that wrong.

575
00:31:23.370 --> 00:31:30.230
>> [LAUGH] Man, yes, so, c from where
you start Tabbing, and then you enter.

576
00:31:30.230 --> 00:31:35.669
It will carriage return down to the next
row from where you started Tabbing from.

577
00:31:35.669 --> 00:31:38.450
So Tab, Tab, Tab, Enter,
Tab, Tab, Tab, Enter.

578
00:31:38.450 --> 00:31:41.900
Now, if I Enter, again,
I am like kinda cancel it out.

579
00:31:41.900 --> 00:31:46.761
So, it has to be in succession if I Tab,
Tab, Tab, Enter, Tab, Tab,

580
00:31:46.761 --> 00:31:50.503
Tab, Enter, Tab, Tab,
right arrow, right arrow.

581
00:31:50.503 --> 00:31:54.100
Do you see how now the Enter,
it's like it gets out of its cycle.

582
00:31:54.100 --> 00:31:57.809
You have to use them in conjunction,
Tab, Enter, Tab, Enter.

583
00:31:57.809 --> 00:32:02.764
You do anything else, it stops
the remembrance of the starting point and

584
00:32:02.764 --> 00:32:05.200
gets you out of the loop.

585
00:32:05.200 --> 00:32:07.826
So, okay, I know that was a little late.

586
00:32:07.826 --> 00:32:09.970
I know I've looked over at

00:32:09.970 --> 00:32:11.382
And I'm a couple minutes over, but

00:32:11.382 --> 00:32:13.841
I couldn't leave this episode
without at least covering it.

589
00:32:13.841 --> 00:32:16.646
Because I realized in my
notes that I skipped over it.

590
00:32:16.646 --> 00:32:20.380
But we'll be using this in some other

591
00:32:20.380 --> 00:32:24.599
So hope that was some good ah-ha moments,
maybe.

592
00:32:24.599 --> 00:32:27.840
Getting around a workbook or worksheet
that you thought would be pretty simple.

593
00:32:27.840 --> 00:32:31.735
But hopefully, you can now take a break,

594
00:32:31.735 --> 00:32:34.623
Make sure you watch those
icons are gonna be so

00:32:34.623 --> 00:32:37.367
important to just use Excel all together.

596
00:32:37.367 --> 00:32:38.160
>> Well Vaughan,

597
00:32:38.160 --> 00:32:42.743
you've definitely helped me increase my
productivity because that Tab-Enter thing.

00:32:42.743 --> 00:32:46.924
There are so many times when I've used the

599
00:32:46.924 --> 00:32:48.352
back to my original point.

600
00:32:48.352 --> 00:32:50.530
Gonna have to file that away,

Remember all these tips and tricks

00:32:53.803 --> 00:32:56.087

in Excel Essentials.

603
00:32:56.087 --> 00:32:57.857
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

604
00:32:57.857 --> 00:33:00.630
So signing of OfficeProTV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

605
00:33:00.630 --> 00:33:01.465
>> And I'm Vuaghan Smith.

606
00:33:01.465 --> 00:33:02.362

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore the multiple ways that you can select and work with cells in Excel. They demonstrate  click/hold/drag, deselecting, range selecting, selecting with shift and arrow keys, select all, select multiple worksheets, select text in multiple worksheets, named ranges, and how to use find and replace.
episodes.title: Select Cells
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

And we actually talked about this

00:00:53.475 --> 00:00:59.190
the things I'm gonna show you are kind

So just kinda keep this in mind and

I think I told you to say

So, you're gonna show

and I enjoy a good keyboard shortcut

00:01:21.875 --> 00:01:23.915
I'm kinda interested to

>> All right, yeah, well, you had so many

00:01:28.315 --> 00:01:32.000

All right, so

Let's jump down in the computer,

00:02:07.980 --> 00:02:09.128
That is cell D5.

I single-clicked, so
if I wanna select a single cell,

you single-click, and

39

Okay, perfect.

So, white plus sign.

46

Oops, sorry,
my mouse moved over a little bit.

White plus sign, click, hold,

48

49

Anytime you have a selected range of

So you can click, hold, and drag with

55

We're going to actually be

00:29:23.332 --> 00:29:27.332

529
00:29:28.222 --> 00:29:34.319

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore the variety of ways that you can insert data into your Excel worksheet. Here they cover: entering data into a cell, editing data in a cell, data and cell overflow, autocorrect options, move data to new cell, and clear cell data.
episodes.title: Insert Data

WEBVTT

Now, when we have the,

So just, again, Insert, if you know you
need to kinda move things around and

440
00:25:47.900 --> 00:25:52.410
put things in new columns or
put things in new rows, just think about

441
00:25:52.410 --> 00:25:56.230
putting in the new columns or
rows first before you start copying and

442
00:25:56.230 --> 00:25:59.130
pasting because then it will make
your life a little bit easier.

443
00:25:59.130 --> 00:26:04.291
And the whole Insert Copied Cells does
depend on whether you're doing it

444
00:26:04.291 --> 00:26:09.900
by the column, meaning selecting
the column, or by the cells, okay?

445
00:26:09.900 --> 00:26:14.140
I know that's a little open-ended, and
I know that's a little kind of like,

446
00:26:14.140 --> 00:26:18.460
I'm not feeling very solid
on this whole topic.

447
00:26:20.540 --> 00:26:23.140
Just be aware, okay,
slow down, think about it.

448
00:26:23.140 --> 00:26:25.212
I need a new column,
Insert the column first.

449
00:26:25.212 --> 00:26:26.735
I wanna take this and put it over here.

450
00:26:26.735 --> 00:26:28.516
Okay, do that second, okay?

451
00:26:28.516 --> 00:26:31.714
So modify your spaces with
your workbook rows and

452
00:26:31.714 --> 00:26:34.700
columns before you start going and
copying.

453
00:26:34.700 --> 00:26:39.310
Get the destination space set first and
then put it into it.

454
00:26:39.310 --> 00:26:42.765
>> So this same exact thing happens if
I did rows, like row selections and

455
00:26:42.765 --> 00:26:43.712
things like that?

456
00:26:43.712 --> 00:26:49.030
>> Correct, yes, and if I wanted to
Insert, just put a new row by itself.

457
00:26:49.030 --> 00:26:51.830
Okay, cuz that's where
I wanted to take this.

458
00:26:51.830 --> 00:26:57.230
And Copy it because I wanted
to put that right here, okay?

459
00:26:58.280 --> 00:27:02.880
Whether I'm selecting a row
versus selecting cells.

460
00:27:04.000 --> 00:27:05.955
Big deal, and the same thing.

461
00:27:05.955 --> 00:27:08.230
So just be careful of it.

462
00:27:09.250 --> 00:27:11.230
One last thing I wanna talk about,
I've been talking all about Copy,

463
00:27:11.230 --> 00:27:12.710
haven't I, okay?

464
00:27:12.710 --> 00:27:14.010
Yeah, Cut.

465
00:27:14.010 --> 00:27:16.420
What's the difference between Cut and
Copy?

466
00:27:16.420 --> 00:27:21.200
>> So when I think of Cut, I'm like,
I'm removing it in addition to copying it.

467
00:27:21.200 --> 00:27:24.870
It is equivalent to, or
excuse me, I'm removing it and

468
00:27:24.870 --> 00:27:27.366
then putting it in a destination place.

469
00:27:27.366 --> 00:27:29.851
It is equivalent, I've seen people do
this, they'll Copy, they'll Paste, and

470
00:27:29.851 --> 00:27:30.946
then they'll come back and delete.

471
00:27:30.946 --> 00:27:33.177
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, I'm like, just Cut it.

472
00:27:33.177 --> 00:27:34.278
>> Yeah, take it out.

473
00:27:34.278 --> 00:27:35.743
>> So, Cut it is a delete operation.

474
00:27:35.743 --> 00:27:40.000
>> Yeah, just cut it out,
you gotta take it out of there.

475
00:27:40.000 --> 00:27:44.710
Yeah, and the thing with Excel that you
need to be aware of, if I wanted to

476
00:27:44.710 --> 00:27:49.170
remove this for whatever reason,
I'm just grabbing a bunch of cells.

477
00:27:49.170 --> 00:27:53.090
If I Cut this, it doesn't take it out.

478
00:27:53.090 --> 00:27:54.970
And people are like, no,
but I told it to Cut.

479
00:27:54.970 --> 00:28:00.580
It doesn't remove
the information until you Paste.

480
00:28:00.580 --> 00:28:03.300
And you're saying now it takes it out.

481
00:28:03.300 --> 00:28:04.590
So don't let that trip you up.

482
00:28:04.590 --> 00:28:07.690
I was like, why won't you Cut, go away!

483
00:28:07.690 --> 00:28:10.018
No, you gotta just get it down.

484
00:28:10.018 --> 00:28:14.040
You gotta Paste it first, and
that's where it comes into play.

485
00:28:14.040 --> 00:28:17.080
So, something to know about.

486
00:28:17.080 --> 00:28:19.075
Excel just does that, so.

487
00:28:19.075 --> 00:28:22.912
>> Now, Vonne, you said you were gonna
tell us something you were using.

488
00:28:22.912 --> 00:28:25.130
You were in a trickster
a little while ago.

489
00:28:25.130 --> 00:28:28.940
But when you Cut things, a lot of times
I've run into, you're like, oops,

490
00:28:28.940 --> 00:28:30.760
I cut the wrong thing.

491
00:28:30.760 --> 00:28:33.140
I need to roll it back.

492
00:28:33.140 --> 00:28:37.032
You did that a little while ago, but
you said, I will come back to that.

493
00:28:37.032 --> 00:28:40.230
I think this might be a good time to say,
how do I roll that back?

494
00:28:40.230 --> 00:28:42.130
>> I'm so glad you reminded me about that.

495
00:28:42.130 --> 00:28:46.930
Yes, our best friend in the world, Undo.

496
00:28:46.930 --> 00:28:49.510
My gosh, couldn't live without it, okay?

497
00:28:49.510 --> 00:28:53.620
Undo is go back in time,
go back in my history.

498
00:28:53.620 --> 00:28:57.660
Undo, up at the top,
notice it says Z in there.

499
00:28:57.660 --> 00:28:59.886
Z, and we were talking about
this before the episode.

500
00:28:59.886 --> 00:29:04.860
Cmd+Z, or Ctrl+Z in a PC,
it's kind of across the board for

501
00:29:04.860 --> 00:29:08.320
most programs,
that that will take you back.

502
00:29:08.320 --> 00:29:14.413
So I'm doing Cmd+Z, taking me back,
but I could also click this button.

503
00:29:14.413 --> 00:29:16.650
The other thing is like,
look what just happened.

504
00:29:16.650 --> 00:29:18.610
I'm not in Christmas Cats anymore, am I?

505
00:29:18.610 --> 00:29:19.730
I'm in Navigate a Workbook.

506
00:29:19.730 --> 00:29:23.420
If I keep going backwards,
back, back, keep on going back.

507
00:29:23.420 --> 00:29:24.980
How far we going back?

508
00:29:24.980 --> 00:29:28.280
Way back, and
it goes a little something like this.

509
00:29:28.280 --> 00:29:32.390
So, how long can I go backwards, right?

510
00:29:32.390 --> 00:29:36.470
Well, there is a whole list right here.

511
00:29:36.470 --> 00:29:40.914
I can drop this down, and
I can go as far back, well,

512
00:29:40.914 --> 00:29:43.959
kind of as far back as I want to here.

513
00:29:43.959 --> 00:29:45.660
Now, I don't remember where that was.

514
00:29:45.660 --> 00:29:49.990
So I usually go step by step
by step by step by step

515
00:29:49.990 --> 00:29:54.409
to keep on going backwards until I
kinda figure out where I'm going.

516
00:29:55.490 --> 00:29:59.040
If you can go back,
you can also go forward.

517
00:29:59.040 --> 00:30:05.179
I can go forward, forward, forward,
keep on going, keep on going, or Cmd+Y.

518
00:30:05.179 --> 00:30:12.068
So I just keep on doing my Cmd+Y, and
I can keep on forwarding [LAUGH].

519
00:30:12.068 --> 00:30:17.716
Going back and redoing all that,
and so that's, yes, Undo,

520
00:30:17.716 --> 00:30:22.949
you ever go, oops,
hit the Undo button or do your Cmd+Z.

521
00:30:22.949 --> 00:30:27.590
If you wanna Redo it, you do Cmd+Y.

522
00:30:27.590 --> 00:30:33.021
It does go across all of our workbooks,
everything that I've done in Excel.

523
00:30:33.021 --> 00:30:38.606
>> All right, so that's the currently open
workbook, so if I have multiple workbooks

524
00:30:38.606 --> 00:30:43.971
open, if I were to close a workbook, do
those get removed from the Undo history?

525
00:30:43.971 --> 00:30:47.315
>> I'm gonna say yes [LAUGH].

526
00:30:47.315 --> 00:30:48.290
We could try it.

527
00:30:48.290 --> 00:30:49.930
>> Let's just,
let's give it a whirl, right?

528
00:30:49.930 --> 00:30:52.319
>> Let's do it.
>> Take it for a spin, so to speak.

529
00:30:52.319 --> 00:30:55.009
>> Okay,
we're going to not save the changes.

530
00:30:55.009 --> 00:30:59.720
And yeah, that's how far I went
back in Christmas Cats example.

531
00:30:59.720 --> 00:31:02.850
So, but ooh, but look,
I did all of that in there, too.

532
00:31:02.850 --> 00:31:04.030
Remember this?

533
00:31:04.030 --> 00:31:05.590
I can't Undo that far back.

534
00:31:05.590 --> 00:31:09.980
So yeah, I guess it took wherever
it was and it cut the history off.

535
00:31:09.980 --> 00:31:12.502
And maybe not let me Undo anymore.

536
00:31:12.502 --> 00:31:16.130
So ooh,
that might be a little scary about that.

537
00:31:16.130 --> 00:31:18.727
So, [SOUND], be careful about that.

538
00:31:18.727 --> 00:31:24.500
It doesn't, this is where, back up, and if
you don't, at worst, you know what you do?

539
00:31:24.500 --> 00:31:28.340
You Close, you Don't Save,
and you just say,

540
00:31:28.340 --> 00:31:31.900
nope, I'm not gonna save any of my
changes cuz I don't remember how far.

541
00:31:31.900 --> 00:31:35.618
I just need to go back to where
I had no workbooks open, and

542
00:31:35.618 --> 00:31:39.194
then I have a new starting
point from where I need to go.

543
00:31:39.194 --> 00:31:41.755
And just a little bit of history,

544
00:31:41.755 --> 00:31:45.790
do you know how many Undos
that you can have in Excel?

545
00:31:46.850 --> 00:31:48.640
>> Total for an open Excel session?

546
00:31:48.640 --> 00:31:52.477
>> Yea, like how many Undos
is it going to log for me?

547
00:31:52.477 --> 00:31:54.345
>> 65,536?

548
00:31:54.345 --> 00:31:56.419
>> [SOUND] No [LAUGH].

549
00:31:56.419 --> 00:31:58.984
>> 12 [LAUGH].

550
00:31:58.984 --> 00:32:00.538
>> 100.

551
00:32:00.538 --> 00:32:02.033
>> I was close [LAUGH].

552
00:32:02.033 --> 00:32:08.207
>> Yes, it will take 100 for you, and
that's how many Undos it will remember.

553
00:32:08.207 --> 00:32:11.705
But yeah, as we saw, if we have multiple
workbooks, it can cut that off, and

554
00:32:11.705 --> 00:32:13.657
you might have done a hundred things,
but then you close one and

555
00:32:13.657 --> 00:32:15.135
then it takes all that other stuff out.

556
00:32:15.135 --> 00:32:17.795
So it can be a, your mileage may vary.

557
00:32:19.940 --> 00:32:22.990
>> Well, that is definitely great
words of advice there, Vonne.

558
00:32:22.990 --> 00:32:27.330
And you've shown us a lot more
than I anticipated from just

559
00:32:27.330 --> 00:32:30.650
what I consider a simpler operation.

560
00:32:30.650 --> 00:32:34.130
Definitely some of those gotcha moments
are, you need to remind us, right?

561
00:32:34.130 --> 00:32:37.750
That whole Copy and Paste columns and
all that shenanigans.

562
00:32:37.750 --> 00:32:40.220
Definitely keep those in mind because
those can lead to frustration.

563
00:32:40.220 --> 00:32:44.150
And well, a frustrated individual
is an unproductive individual.

564
00:32:44.150 --> 00:32:46.900
So we want you to stay productive,
so don't be frustrated.

565
00:32:46.900 --> 00:32:47.790
But before we go,

566
00:32:47.790 --> 00:32:51.390
looks like Vonne's got one last thing
to tell us before we get outta here.

567
00:32:51.390 --> 00:32:55.410
>> I know we're already past our time on
this episode of hey, we've gotta go, but

568
00:32:55.410 --> 00:32:58.690
I do want to allude to one thing, and
I'm just gonna keep it as a cliffhanger.

569
00:32:58.690 --> 00:33:00.600
I'll show it in the next episode.

570
00:33:00.600 --> 00:33:03.080
I didn't show you how to Copy and
Paste from Word.

571
00:33:03.080 --> 00:33:04.870
And there's a cute little things on there.

572
00:33:04.870 --> 00:33:05.990
So you know what,
I'm just gonna go ahead and

573
00:33:05.990 --> 00:33:10.460
tack that on in the next one and
just have a continuation on that.

574
00:33:10.460 --> 00:33:12.160
So, remind me, okay?

575
00:33:12.160 --> 00:33:13.756
I'm gonna make a note on myself,
too [LAUGH].

576
00:33:13.756 --> 00:33:16.130
>> Well, we definitely have
a nailbiter there, everyone.

577
00:33:16.130 --> 00:33:19.440
So definitely join us back as
we see how that all plays out.

578
00:33:19.440 --> 00:33:20.810
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
get outta here.

579
00:33:20.810 --> 00:33:23.820
So signing off for OfficePro.TV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

580
00:33:23.820 --> 00:33:24.640
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

581
00:33:24.640 --> 00:33:26.398
>> And we'll see you next time.

582
00:33:26.398 --> 00:33:31.673
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore how to fill series of data. This feature expands the way you copy and paste data and will predict ranges like dates and common item lists.
episodes.title: Fill Series
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.137 --> 00:00:16.429
Greetings everyone and welcome back to
another exciting episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:16.429 --> 00:00:17.481
I'm your host Justin Dennison.

4
00:00:17.481 --> 00:00:21.858
And we're continuing on with our Excel
2016 essentials for Mac series and well,

5
00:00:21.858 --> 00:00:24.607
we're actually gonna be
talking about fill series.

6
00:00:24.607 --> 00:00:26.056
Well, be careful there.

7
00:00:26.056 --> 00:00:29.961
I've said the word series two different
times, but they mean two different things.

8
00:00:29.961 --> 00:00:31.935
And hopefully to make us less confused,

9
00:00:31.935 --> 00:00:35.309
we have someone in the studio who
will help us out, Ms. Vonne Smith.

10
00:00:35.309 --> 00:00:37.082
How are you doing today, Vonne?
>> Good,

11
00:00:37.082 --> 00:00:38.562
I just realized you did say it twice.

12
00:00:38.562 --> 00:00:46.002
I was like the series of the show and
the fill series that we're going to do.

13
00:00:46.002 --> 00:00:47.830
I see what you did there.

14
00:00:47.830 --> 00:00:48.869
Good job.

15
00:00:48.869 --> 00:00:51.351
[LAUGH]
>> I do try to make it, well,

16
00:00:51.351 --> 00:00:54.231
at least engaging, but fill series.

17
00:00:54.231 --> 00:00:58.407
I've used Excel before,
I know where we're going, but

18
00:00:58.407 --> 00:01:01.630
maybe I should ask where
do we need to start?

19
00:01:01.630 --> 00:01:04.663
Is there any things that we need
to know before we really dive

20
00:01:04.663 --> 00:01:05.258
in?
>> Well,

21
00:01:05.258 --> 00:01:08.779
there is one thing that we're gonna
start with that has nothing to do with

22
00:01:08.779 --> 00:01:10.000
fill series.

23
00:01:10.000 --> 00:01:13.502
Because I told you about
it in the last episode,

24
00:01:13.502 --> 00:01:16.929
if you're watching in,
series of our shows.

25
00:01:16.929 --> 00:01:21.165
You know that I had one last thing
to talk about with copy and paste.

26
00:01:21.165 --> 00:01:27.168
I know, it's crazy, it's going into
a second episode with copy and paste.

27
00:01:27.168 --> 00:01:29.476
But it does pertain somewhat,

28
00:01:29.476 --> 00:01:35.532
somehow to the fill series that we will be
doing in this episode that is the title.

29
00:01:35.532 --> 00:01:36.784
So why don't we get started?

30
00:01:36.784 --> 00:01:38.262
Let's jump down into here.

31
00:01:38.262 --> 00:01:39.479
I already have a workbook open.

32
00:01:39.479 --> 00:01:41.282
It's the one that we
were working with before.

33
00:01:41.282 --> 00:01:43.362
And we'll keep on doing
some more stuff with it.

34
00:01:43.362 --> 00:01:47.937
So this is the navigate a workbook,
talk about Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V, we copied,

35
00:01:47.937 --> 00:01:51.011
we did all sorts of things
with our paste options, and

36
00:01:51.011 --> 00:01:55.310
talked about how you can really
get tripped up with everything.

37
00:01:55.310 --> 00:02:00.450
So the last thing I wanted to show
you was copying from other sources.

38
00:02:00.450 --> 00:02:03.837
Now, there's a ton of other
sources that you can go ahead and

39
00:02:03.837 --> 00:02:07.028
get information from,
a Word document, a PowerPoint,

40
00:02:07.028 --> 00:02:11.250
whatever application you're working with,
the Internet.

41
00:02:11.250 --> 00:02:14.867
I'm gonna just stick with Word since
it is a part of the Office series and

42
00:02:14.867 --> 00:02:16.932
you can kind of go back and forth with it.

43
00:02:16.932 --> 00:02:19.417
So I wanna show you a few
little nuisances about that.

44
00:02:19.417 --> 00:02:23.827
And then I just realized that I forgot
to open up the Word document, so

45
00:02:23.827 --> 00:02:25.980
why don't I do that, all right?

46
00:02:25.980 --> 00:02:30.835
So I have a file called Copy for
Excel it will open up in Word.

47
00:02:30.835 --> 00:02:35.219
And in Word totally not Excel,
Excel is in rows and columns and

48
00:02:35.219 --> 00:02:38.100
cells here we have paragraphs, right?

49
00:02:38.100 --> 00:02:41.932
Every time you hit the Enter key on
the keyboard you're making a paragraph.

50
00:02:41.932 --> 00:02:46.442
I also have my show on high characters
on right now even if you don't know

51
00:02:46.442 --> 00:02:51.403
anything about Word, I have a whole series
on that, I have three series on it,

52
00:02:51.403 --> 00:02:52.620
love me some Word.

53
00:02:52.620 --> 00:02:56.996
So if I scroll on down to here,
notice that we just have some paragraphs.

54
00:02:56.996 --> 00:03:04.120
I've got Alice and Bell and Bishop so
Entering every time from here.

55
00:03:04.120 --> 00:03:06.233
Well, if I have something like this.

56
00:03:06.233 --> 00:03:08.043
And I wanna use this in Excel,

57
00:03:08.043 --> 00:03:12.319
because I want to start tracking
their favorite food or their treats,

58
00:03:12.319 --> 00:03:17.050
or what have you, it would be easier
to do in a tabular-type format.

59
00:03:17.050 --> 00:03:19.741
So, why don't I go ahead and
start from there?

60
00:03:19.741 --> 00:03:22.040
Great point, and yeah, we're gonna do it.

61
00:03:22.040 --> 00:03:22.783
So you're gonna click, hold and drag.

62
00:03:22.783 --> 00:03:25.744
We're gonna select all of
the paragraphs within this

63
00:03:25.744 --> 00:03:28.640
particular page of this document.

64
00:03:28.640 --> 00:03:31.609
I'll right click so
you guys can see me copying or

65
00:03:31.609 --> 00:03:34.006
Cmd+C, I forget we're in Mac still.

66
00:03:34.006 --> 00:03:37.660
[LAUGH] Let's pop on over to Excel.

67
00:03:38.930 --> 00:03:43.927
I'm gonna go over here to Sheet 3 just so
we can have a little bit blank space and

68
00:03:43.927 --> 00:03:45.842
I'm gonna start right here.

69
00:03:45.842 --> 00:03:50.657
The biggest thing to
remember about copying and

70
00:03:50.657 --> 00:03:55.770
pasting from Word to Excel
is do not double click.

71
00:03:55.770 --> 00:03:59.587
Do not activate your cursor into
the cell If you select one cell,

72
00:03:59.587 --> 00:04:03.968
you don't even have to select anything
else, you don't select a range,

73
00:04:03.968 --> 00:04:07.518
just a single one where we
wanted to start, and just paste.

74
00:04:07.518 --> 00:04:12.265
It will come in as individual rows.

75
00:04:12.265 --> 00:04:16.083
So now Bell has its own cell,
Bishop, Blossom, Brandy, and so

76
00:04:16.083 --> 00:04:18.149
you can go on down, oops, sorry.

77
00:04:18.149 --> 00:04:22.079
I was getting a little fancy and I dragged
and I was trying to move something and

78
00:04:22.079 --> 00:04:26.035
it was trying to replace the information
so that's why it got a little wonky.

79
00:04:26.035 --> 00:04:27.731
But that's pretty cool, all right?

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne go through the common file types supported by Excel 2016. Here they explain .xlsx files, Comma Separated Value(.csv) files, OpenDocument Spreadsheet(.ods) files, and Excel Templates(.xltx) files.

I have a whole episode on using templates
in Excel in the advanced series,

485
00:27:50.630 --> 00:27:55.620
but just really quickly
the file format is an XLTX.

486
00:27:55.620 --> 00:28:00.350
So, template, and then you would
just do a File > Save As, and

487
00:28:00.350 --> 00:28:02.390
then you change it to a template.

488
00:28:02.390 --> 00:28:07.000
And do notice that right here, do you
see like the path of like, goodness,

489
00:28:07.000 --> 00:28:08.400
where am I, right?

490
00:28:08.400 --> 00:28:10.920
Do not change the directory.

491
00:28:10.920 --> 00:28:14.030
Because if you change the directory
it won't understand it.

492
00:28:14.030 --> 00:28:18.750
So, you need to do that in a template
is one of those like when we did a file

493
00:28:18.750 --> 00:28:22.130
new form template where we
have these starting points.

494
00:28:22.130 --> 00:28:27.450
You will then have you're own templates
to be able to have like a starting point,

495
00:28:27.450 --> 00:28:33.195
like a stamp, and
then you create a new file excel file.

496
00:28:33.195 --> 00:28:34.262
So, XLS.

497
00:28:35.400 --> 00:28:41.556
Templates, you make it and
you save it as an Excel SLSX file.

498
00:28:41.556 --> 00:28:45.097
More on that in that particular episode
of that single little circular unit, and

499
00:28:45.097 --> 00:28:46.565
you're just kind of like.

500
00:28:46.565 --> 00:28:49.375
I'll tell you more about it,
but it is a file type, so

501
00:28:49.375 --> 00:28:53.140
I at least wanted to go ahead and
mention it in this episode.

502
00:28:53.140 --> 00:28:54.840
And there we go.

503
00:28:54.840 --> 00:28:58.240
Definitely read up on all of
that kinda fun and coding stuff.

504
00:28:58.240 --> 00:29:01.180
It's very geeky and it's very technical.

505
00:29:01.180 --> 00:29:05.080
Since I do a lot of stuff with text, and
fonts, and font faces and open type fonts,

506
00:29:06.450 --> 00:29:11.060
this is kind of one of
my little geek session,

507
00:29:11.060 --> 00:29:13.700
so we all have them and
that's fine [LAUGH].

508
00:29:13.700 --> 00:29:16.820
>> Well, Von, you've definitely geeked
out to me before, but all I know is

509
00:29:16.820 --> 00:29:21.080
the different coding types tends to cause
me horrible pain from time to time.

510
00:29:21.080 --> 00:29:25.030
But if you're aware of them,
you can alleviate that a fair amount.

511
00:29:25.030 --> 00:29:28.120
Well, thank you for
reviewing all those file types, and

512
00:29:28.120 --> 00:29:32.040
exports, and
all of those weird nuance behaviors like.

513
00:29:32.040 --> 00:29:35.000
I save as a CSV, kind of.

514
00:29:35.000 --> 00:29:39.070
But now, I need to close it, don't save,
re-open, and now I'm good to go.

515
00:29:39.070 --> 00:29:40.710
So, do keep that in mind,

516
00:29:40.710 --> 00:29:44.180
because you don't want to get
lost in your own computer.

517
00:29:44.180 --> 00:29:47.173
And speaking of getting lost, definitely
don't get lost, so you can come on back.

518
00:29:47.173 --> 00:29:48.860
But we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

519
00:29:48.860 --> 00:29:51.970
So, signing off for OfficeProTV,
I've been your host Justin Denison.

520
00:29:51.970 --> 00:29:52.840
>> And I'm Von Smith.

521
00:29:52.840 --> 00:29:54.180
>> And we'll see you next time.

522
00:29:54.180 --> 00:29:59.360
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore modifying a worksheet in Excel 2016. They demonstrate how to select columns and rows, change column height and row width, insert and delete rows/columns, hide columns and rows, merge cells, and apply word wrap to cells.
episodes.title: Modify a Worksheet
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:09.658
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.539 --> 00:00:15.568
Greetings everyone, and welcome back to
another exciting episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:15.568 --> 00:00:17.638
I'm your host, Justin Dennison, and

4
00:00:17.638 --> 00:00:21.550
we're continuing on with our Excel
2016 Essentials for Mac series.

5
00:00:21.550 --> 00:00:26.211
And we're gonna be modifying a workbook,
actually modifying a worksheet, I'm sorry.

6
00:00:27.390 --> 00:00:29.920
Those terms just kind of roll
off the tongue sometimes.

7
00:00:29.920 --> 00:00:34.220
But luckily we have someone better
versed in it than I, Miss Vonne Smith.

8
00:00:34.220 --> 00:00:35.816
How you doing today, Vonne?
>> I'm doing pretty good.

9
00:00:35.816 --> 00:00:40.895
And hey, I get them confused all the time
too, so [LAUGH] I totally feel you there.

10
00:00:40.895 --> 00:00:46.830
But yes, we are getting into a new topic
right now called format workbooks.

11
00:00:46.830 --> 00:00:50.905
Okay, the term format, it can mean modify,

12
00:00:50.905 --> 00:00:54.783
it can mean change, make look different.

13
00:00:54.783 --> 00:00:59.566
Jazz it up a little bit, right,
gussy it up as I like to always say.

14
00:00:59.566 --> 00:01:01.982
I mean we have some other
terminology I'm sure there Justin.

15
00:01:01.982 --> 00:01:04.382
>> [LAUGH] I don't know about those.

16
00:01:04.382 --> 00:01:05.240
>> [LAUGH]

17
00:01:05.240 --> 00:01:06.650
>> It's funny, when I hear format,

18
00:01:06.650 --> 00:01:08.458
and I'm in a computer
land I start to panic.

19
00:01:08.458 --> 00:01:12.316
Because I'm not saying I have, but I might
have formatted a couple of drives before,

20
00:01:12.316 --> 00:01:14.417
which actually has
a different connotation.

21
00:01:14.417 --> 00:01:17.947
So if you're one of those, maybe a little
more technical-savvy than others,

22
00:01:17.947 --> 00:01:19.017
and you're like format.

23
00:01:19.017 --> 00:01:20.447
No, this is not what I wanna do.

24
00:01:20.447 --> 00:01:23.657
Well format in this term is,
we're gonna guess it up,

25
00:01:23.657 --> 00:01:26.517
hang some trim on it,
slap a coat of paint on it.

26
00:01:26.517 --> 00:01:31.760
Or maybe just make it look a little bit
different, change it a little, who knows?

27
00:01:31.760 --> 00:01:35.434
And well, who better knows than her?
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, I mean,

28
00:01:35.434 --> 00:01:38.225
if you format a hard drive,
you are changing it.

29
00:01:38.225 --> 00:01:39.920
So I guess it's all the same.

30
00:01:39.920 --> 00:01:40.440
But you know what?

31
00:01:40.440 --> 00:01:41.685
Tomato, tomato, what are we doing?

32
00:01:41.685 --> 00:01:45.910
We're gonna be messing around with columns
and we're gonna be merging some things.

33
00:01:45.910 --> 00:01:47.700
So it's just making it look pretty.

34
00:01:47.700 --> 00:01:49.887
Why don't we jump down and
show you a few things?

35
00:01:49.887 --> 00:01:53.895
Now I have a file called Modify
a Worksheet, that's cool.

36
00:01:53.895 --> 00:01:57.842
Cuz we do have a separate episode
about modifying a workbook.

37
00:01:57.842 --> 00:01:59.767
And that's in a different connotation.

38
00:01:59.767 --> 00:02:02.860
So this is just the sheet versus the book.

39
00:02:02.860 --> 00:02:06.300
I also have another file,
I did a command tilday by the way,

40
00:02:06.300 --> 00:02:10.818
of my keyboard shortcut, to flip between
open workbooks within the application.

41
00:02:10.818 --> 00:02:13.700
This is our Christmas cats example,
ya'll been seeing it.

42
00:02:13.700 --> 00:02:17.000
But throughout these next episodes,
as we go through these,

43
00:02:17.000 --> 00:02:20.940
we're gonna end up making everything
look very similar to this.

44
00:02:20.940 --> 00:02:26.820
As you can see, this looks completely
different than say this, okay?

45
00:02:26.820 --> 00:02:30.820
And I know I'm zoomed out, or
I don't have the text very big.

46
00:02:30.820 --> 00:02:37.070
But this information from this worksheet
to this worksheet and this workbook.

47
00:02:37.070 --> 00:02:39.160
They're the same thing.

48
00:02:39.160 --> 00:02:40.980
They just look completely different.

49
00:02:40.980 --> 00:02:42.900
It's got a lot of pretty paint on it,
right?

50
00:02:42.900 --> 00:02:44.790
So that's what we're going to start doing.

51
00:02:44.790 --> 00:02:48.010
But before we get into colors,
and fonts and

52
00:02:48.010 --> 00:02:52.940
all that kind of fun stuff, we just need
to, hey, let's talk about our rows, and

53
00:02:52.940 --> 00:02:57.140
columns and our cells, first of all.

54
00:02:57.140 --> 00:03:00.548
So let's get into our columns and rows.

55
00:03:00.548 --> 00:03:05.420
And I'm gonna zoom so
you can see this a little bit clearer.

56
00:03:05.420 --> 00:03:07.320
We got our columns across the top and
our rows.

57
00:03:07.320 --> 00:03:10.510
Now this is some of the things we
have talked about in other episodes.

58
00:03:10.510 --> 00:03:13.770
So if it seems like it's repetitive,
it is.

59
00:03:13.770 --> 00:03:18.810
We have our black arrow pointing
down on our column references.

60
00:03:18.810 --> 00:03:23.730
This means that we will be
selecting our entire column.

61
00:03:23.730 --> 00:03:25.251
The same thing as if I move over here.

62
00:03:25.251 --> 00:03:27.830
I get a black arrow pointing to the right.

63
00:03:27.830 --> 00:03:30.750
That's where I can select my rows.

64
00:03:30.750 --> 00:03:34.689
Cuz if we're gonna be adding rows,
inserting rows, deleting rows,

65
00:03:34.689 --> 00:03:38.046
selecting rows or columns,
you need to know how to do that.

66
00:03:38.046 --> 00:03:44.460
So if I told you, hey, go ahead and
select all of column E.

67
00:03:44.460 --> 00:03:46.190
That means you'd come over to column E,

68
00:03:46.190 --> 00:03:48.450
you'd single click that
black arrow pointing down.

69
00:03:48.450 --> 00:03:50.880
And you would select that whole column,

70
00:03:50.880 --> 00:03:53.220
all the way down to
the bottom of the worksheet.

71
00:03:54.590 --> 00:03:58.020
If I told you to select columns B,
C and D,

72
00:03:58.020 --> 00:04:01.910
then that would be,
take your black pointed arrow.

73
00:04:01.910 --> 00:04:05.790
Hold and drag across, just like if
I was selecting a range of cells,

74
00:04:05.790 --> 00:04:10.570
you can select a range of
columns within this worksheet.

75
00:04:10.570 --> 00:04:13.390
Same thing with rows, and I should
probably also say, hey, if I tell you to

76
00:04:13.390 --> 00:04:17.390
deselect this, like click off of this,
just means click off on some blank cell.

77
00:04:17.390 --> 00:04:20.530
And then it turns off that selection.

78
00:04:20.530 --> 00:04:23.750
Same thing with our rows, but
you need to make sure you're looking for

79
00:04:23.750 --> 00:04:28.730
the right mouse cursor icon of the black
arrows, not the ones in between it.

80
00:04:28.730 --> 00:04:33.250
That does something different,
because the in between

81
00:04:33.250 --> 00:04:37.610
changes your column widths or
your row heights.

82
00:04:37.610 --> 00:04:40.610
Talks about in another episode,
hey, right here in column E,

83
00:04:40.610 --> 00:04:45.280
you can see that this actually
says 333 Rabbit Hole Lane.

84
00:04:45.280 --> 00:04:47.310
So that is what's in it, but

85
00:04:47.310 --> 00:04:52.450
since I have another entry right over
here in Tampa, it's cutting it off.

86
00:04:52.450 --> 00:04:54.600
So why I can't see it?

87
00:04:54.600 --> 00:04:56.531
Well, just make the column wider, okay?

88
00:04:56.531 --> 00:05:00.268
Nothing says you have to keep the columns
exactly like they are by default,

89
00:05:00.268 --> 00:05:01.710
make them bigger.

90
00:05:01.710 --> 00:05:06.260
So if I come up to the in
between part between E and

91
00:05:06.260 --> 00:05:09.879
F, I get a line with two
arrows pointing off the side.

92
00:05:11.120 --> 00:05:12.990
That indicates change the column width.

93
00:05:14.020 --> 00:05:18.250
The first way that you can do this
is if you just click, hold and drag.

94
00:05:18.250 --> 00:05:19.552
I'm gonna click, hold,

95
00:05:19.552 --> 00:05:23.270
notice it does show you a little
tooltip of how wide it's getting.

96
00:05:23.270 --> 00:05:28.350
It doesn't show you a preview of moving,
if you wanna say, making it wider.

97
00:05:28.350 --> 00:05:31.290
If you let go, notice that,
all right, it made it wider.

98
00:05:31.290 --> 00:05:33.840
So I make it a little bit more,
make it a little bit more.

99
00:05:33.840 --> 00:05:37.280
And, if I zoom out, did I get it to,
yep, all right, perfect.

100
00:05:37.280 --> 00:05:41.488
I have made this column wide enough
to be able show all the content.

101
00:05:41.488 --> 00:05:43.302
So you could do that with all of them.

102
00:05:43.302 --> 00:05:45.790
And I can come into here and
click, hold and drag.

103
00:05:45.790 --> 00:05:49.263
I can come over here click, hold and
drag, so I can make this column wider.

104
00:05:49.263 --> 00:05:55.000
But there's also something cool that you
can do, and that is known as AutoFit.

105
00:05:55.000 --> 00:05:58.724
Do you know this one, Justin?
>> This is actually my default behavior.

106
00:05:58.724 --> 00:06:01.780
I'm like click, click and yay!

107
00:06:01.780 --> 00:06:05.190
But sometimes,
I do run into some odd issues.

108
00:06:05.190 --> 00:06:06.870
And I suspect you're
gonna highlight those.

109
00:06:06.870 --> 00:06:08.640
So I'm not going to steal
your thunder on that one.

110
00:06:08.640 --> 00:06:10.990
But yep, double-click,
makes it easy for me.

111
00:06:10.990 --> 00:06:12.890
>> So much easier, yes, I love that.

112
00:06:12.890 --> 00:06:15.110
I love how you're like that's
just my default action.

113
00:06:15.110 --> 00:06:17.118
Yeah like right here, in this column C.

114
00:06:17.118 --> 00:06:21.180
I know that there needs to be a little
bit more space, but how much?

115
00:06:22.210 --> 00:06:27.050
If you come in between the columns and you
double-click, click, click, it AutoFits.

116
00:06:27.050 --> 00:06:33.810
It automatically fits that column to
be as wide as the widest value, neat.

117
00:06:33.810 --> 00:06:35.710
Okay, so the same thing here.

118
00:06:35.710 --> 00:06:38.350
Notice that my column is too wide.

119
00:06:38.350 --> 00:06:42.010
I could do it in reverse, I guess
you could say, it will double-click.

120
00:06:42.010 --> 00:06:45.474
And it will just make it as
wide as it needs to be, neat.

121
00:06:45.474 --> 00:06:50.170
Now the cool thing is if I can
do this with multiple columns.

122
00:06:50.170 --> 00:06:54.300
If I click, hold and
drag between A, B, C and D, and

123
00:06:54.300 --> 00:06:59.685
then come in between any of those columns,
it will AutoFit all of them.

124
00:06:59.685 --> 00:07:01.110
Ooh, that can be kinda cool.

125
00:07:01.110 --> 00:07:06.420
Now, I just selected four of them,
but remember this top button up here,

126
00:07:06.420 --> 00:07:08.218
click that to select everything.

127
00:07:08.218 --> 00:07:11.230
Then just double-click,
doesn't matter which

128
00:07:11.230 --> 00:07:14.690
column you go in between as long as you
get the line with the two pointed arrows.

129
00:07:14.690 --> 00:07:17.680
You double-click, and then it will go
ahead, and notice how these got a little

130
00:07:17.680 --> 00:07:21.730
smaller and everything,
because I don't have any headings.

131
00:07:21.730 --> 00:07:23.440
So I don't have the word state.

132
00:07:23.440 --> 00:07:27.190
If I had the word state in that top
column, it would change the width and

133
00:07:27.190 --> 00:07:27.850
everything like that.

134
00:07:27.850 --> 00:07:33.037
So that's pretty cool,
I love autofitting, it's nice to do.

135
00:07:33.037 --> 00:07:38.370
You can do the same thing with your
row heights and the autofitting.

136
00:07:38.370 --> 00:07:42.910
For example, if I came in between
the row 1 and 2, click, hold and

137
00:07:42.910 --> 00:07:47.790
drag, notice that I can
make the row higher.

138
00:07:47.790 --> 00:07:50.012
We'll come back around to that when
we talk about merging cells and

139
00:07:50.012 --> 00:07:50.933
alignment in a little bit.

140
00:07:50.933 --> 00:07:55.742
But just wanted to tell you that
you can double-click on that,

141
00:07:55.742 --> 00:08:00.293
and it will AutoFit,
row wise not just column wise, cool.

142
00:08:00.293 --> 00:08:05.243
Kinda going back to the, hey, you know
what, I don't really have A top row

143
00:08:05.243 --> 00:08:10.540
with column headers like, is this
the first name, is this the last name?

144
00:08:10.540 --> 00:08:12.410
Is this a phone number?

145
00:08:12.410 --> 00:08:16.040
It looks like it, but
it might not be, I don't know.

146
00:08:16.040 --> 00:08:18.005
Having column headers in any of your,

147
00:08:18.005 --> 00:08:22.150
like kind of lists of data
is pretty important, I feel.

148
00:08:22.150 --> 00:08:24.800
Especially when we get
into mail merges and

149
00:08:24.800 --> 00:08:26.090
everything like that, you gotta have it.

150
00:08:26.090 --> 00:08:30.910
Well, how do I get that in there,
well, you just insert another row.

151
00:08:30.910 --> 00:08:33.520
And this is what kind of throws
people off, it's like but yeah, but

152
00:08:33.520 --> 00:08:37.040
that's row one, I mean though,
you're gonna have two row ones.

153
00:08:37.040 --> 00:08:41.030
No, these are just references,
this is just one big grid.

154
00:08:41.030 --> 00:08:45.100
So if you insert a row or
a column, you're just making,

155
00:08:45.100 --> 00:08:50.240
you're kinda moving things around to
change where the stuff lives in the grid.

156
00:08:50.240 --> 00:08:53.910
And it's kind of a weird thing, that
people can't always wrap their head around

157
00:08:53.910 --> 00:08:58.560
that one of like, one's already there but
now it's making another number one?

158
00:08:58.560 --> 00:09:02.030
No, it's just a reference,
so that's all we're doing.

159
00:09:02.030 --> 00:09:06.622
So if I wanted to insert another
row right here, I'm just going

160
00:09:06.622 --> 00:09:11.684
right-click over the row one with
that arrow pointing to the right.

161
00:09:11.684 --> 00:09:14.936
So right-click,
notice it also does like select it, so

162
00:09:14.936 --> 00:09:16.982
just be a little careful with that.

163
00:09:16.982 --> 00:09:19.908
And I'm going to insert,
so I click it, and

164
00:09:19.908 --> 00:09:24.700
then see, it's still row one and
then everything moves down.

165
00:09:24.700 --> 00:09:25.291
Wanna do it again?

166
00:09:25.291 --> 00:09:28.282
Right-click, insert, cool,

167
00:09:28.282 --> 00:09:33.180
well this is where if I have two of them,
what if I wanted to insert two more?

168
00:09:33.180 --> 00:09:35.650
I really needed four rows.

169
00:09:35.650 --> 00:09:39.840
Well if you select two of them,
then when you right-click and insert,

170
00:09:39.840 --> 00:09:41.400
you're gonna insert two more.

171
00:09:41.400 --> 00:09:44.480
So that can kinda be nice,
to be able to say, hey,

172
00:09:44.480 --> 00:09:48.340
I need to put in two rows
between Frito and Fuego.

173
00:09:48.340 --> 00:09:53.330
Well, you need to get one in there
first and then I have a blank row,

174
00:09:53.330 --> 00:09:55.420
and then I can select it again.

175
00:09:55.420 --> 00:10:01.070
So you can kinda like, I need four more or
two more, you insert and now I have four.

176
00:10:01.070 --> 00:10:05.046
So you can start kinda do
it in exponentially, right?

177
00:10:05.046 --> 00:10:06.640
>> Yeah, that's an exponential growth.

178
00:10:06.640 --> 00:10:12.891
If you continue selecting all the ones
that are now available as blank rows,

179
00:10:12.891 --> 00:10:18.552
it'll be 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, 64, 128, 256,

180
00:10:18.552 --> 00:10:23.514
512, 1024, 2048, 4096, yeah.
>> Okay if you-

181
00:10:23.514 --> 00:10:24.152

Now it doesn't do it anymore because
it doesn't live in F anymore.

640
00:34:15.617 --> 00:34:18.179
It lives in all of these cells,
so that can actually fit.

641
00:34:18.179 --> 00:34:21.694
So a lot times those headings
that I wanna auto fit column A,

642
00:34:21.694 --> 00:34:26.476
I'll merge the cells for my title and that
way I don't have to worry about that and

643
00:34:26.476 --> 00:34:28.990
I can still use my auto fit for
my column A.

644
00:34:28.990 --> 00:34:31.937
[SOUND] So little tip.
>> That has definitely gotten me

645
00:34:31.937 --> 00:34:32.686
a bunch of times.

646
00:34:32.686 --> 00:34:35.815
And it's just, I'm like, yeah I
forgot that's a bunch of text there.

647
00:34:35.815 --> 00:34:38.375
And well that's where
wrapped text comes into play.

648
00:34:38.375 --> 00:34:42.515
Just remember, the auto fit starts acting
wonky when we finally have wrapped text.

649
00:34:42.515 --> 00:34:45.271
And thank you so much Vonne for
giving us those tips and tricks,

650
00:34:45.271 --> 00:34:47.510
and as well as highlighting
a few of those gotchas.

651
00:34:47.510 --> 00:34:49.630
And thank you for
joining us for this episode.

652
00:34:49.630 --> 00:34:53.000
But it is that time,
we are out of time for this episode.

653
00:34:53.000 --> 00:34:55.020
We're gonna get out of here, so
signing off for OfficePro.TV,

654
00:34:55.020 --> 00:34:57.437
I've been your host Justin Dennison.
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

655
00:34:57.437 --> 00:34:58.733
>> And we'll see you next time.

656
00:34:58.733 --> 00:35:05.306
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne show how to format a worksheet in Excel 2016. They cover selecting fonts, aligning cell content, adding borders and shading, and copying formats with the format painter.
episodes.title: Format a Worksheet
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

these are the types of things that are

That can really set your worksheet, and

Formatted worksheet

We don't have that in a MAC world,

[SOUND] it's okay, it doesn't exist.

All right, so that, let's go to it,

When you have a font and

But technically,

00:08:43.167 --> 00:08:44.312

00:08:44.312 --> 00:08:47.850
I think didn't Don say

00:08:47.850 --> 00:08:50.110
He used the terminology and

00:08:50.110 --> 00:08:51.680
And he was like yeah.

00:08:51.680 --> 00:08:54.340
The measurement and
that totally threw me off for a minute.

00:08:54.340 --> 00:08:56.730
But maybe, cuz he's pretty
old school on computer stuff.

175
00:08:56.730 --> 00:08:58.640
So they are on points,

00:08:58.640 --> 00:09:02.200
points is a measurement system
that you just measure fonts in.

00:09:02.200 --> 00:09:05.460
I'll leave it at that, but
there are 72 points in an inch,

00:09:05.460 --> 00:09:08.056
because there are six picas in an inch.
>> And

179
00:09:08.056 --> 00:09:11.210
pica is another measuring system,
don't worry about it.

00:09:11.210 --> 00:09:14.410
We'll go ahead and choose this,
hey, 20 is very good than 12, so

that's what you're gonna get.

These little bumpy buttons right here,

If you come from PC world, something

It just doesn't exist in a Mac world.

So you just have to just know and

00:09:41.970 --> 00:09:46.960

00:09:46.960 --> 00:09:50.316
This is a particular font that whether

00:09:50.316 --> 00:09:51.680
it's not gonna do anything.

00:09:51.680 --> 00:09:53.216
I can make it italic, okay?

00:09:53.216 --> 00:09:57.801
But if I did change this to,
let's just say, just regular Arial, and

00:09:57.801 --> 00:09:59.215

00:09:59.215 --> 00:10:00.735
See now, you can see the difference,

See that's not the cell it lives in,

So these are the colors that

Now, why do I have these particular ones,

Now, look at the different options here.

You have top border,
right border, top and bottom,

00:23:20.570 --> 00:23:24.430
a thick bottom border,
all of that kind of stuff.

437
00:23:24.430 --> 00:23:28.460
If you have like a single line of cells,
and

438
00:23:28.460 --> 00:23:30.740
Iâm just switching back and
forth from worksheets.

00:23:30.740 --> 00:23:34.960
Like for example,
if I had here, daily totals.

00:23:34.960 --> 00:23:36.790
Okay, let's zoom in a little bit.

And I have all selected and

Notice, it's put a thick bottom border

444

But if I select multiple rows, if you want

It does not put a thick bottom

That's what everybody's like, no,

So it's all based on what you have

00:24:16.020 --> 00:24:21.040

So these are for each selection, but

This is another thing that throws people

00:24:36.910 --> 00:24:40.434
So let's go back and do this again,

00:24:47.668 --> 00:24:50.150
So I mean the outside of all my sections,

00:24:50.150 --> 00:24:51.730
I also want to make that

00:24:51.730 --> 00:24:53.140
I don't want it to just be black.

00:24:53.140 --> 00:24:57.440
So they come over here to Line Color,

00:24:57.440 --> 00:24:59.620

00:24:59.620 --> 00:25:01.990
And then you start going whoa, wait, what?

What's going,

It's not a cell selector anymore, because

00:25:14.930 --> 00:25:18.225
Cuz logical, apply the border,

00:25:18.225 --> 00:25:21.061
It's not how it works, and you're
over there, you've done this before,

00:25:21.061 --> 00:25:21.980

>> So

00:25:21.980 --> 00:25:25.510
I could see me throwing my hands up and

00:25:25.510 --> 00:25:29.750
because it's not intuitive, because with

00:25:29.750 --> 00:25:32.650
I select and then I modify the color.

00:25:32.650 --> 00:25:33.888
>> But for borders it puts

you into Draw mode, which I'm gonna be

00:25:38.581 --> 00:25:40.420
I haven't looked at that at all.

00:25:40.420 --> 00:25:41.850
I was like, you can draw a border?

00:25:41.850 --> 00:25:42.960
I didn't know that.

00:25:42.960 --> 00:25:46.188
But if I was trying to change the line

00:25:46.188 --> 00:25:48.228
mode, that would be really confusing.

480
00:25:48.228 --> 00:25:50.350
>> And it's odd that they don't have some

semi-intuitive that supplied the remaining
I guess styles in this case, of like font

482
00:25:55.046 --> 00:25:57.550
color and background color and stuff.
>> And

483
00:25:57.550 --> 00:26:03.260
that's where borders trips people up,
it's not intuitive and it's not logical,

00:26:03.260 --> 00:26:08.190
the way we think of how to select, draw,
you know, apply, change colors, no.

00:26:08.190 --> 00:26:09.803
You have to think of

And the other thing is that whole turn

That's the same thing here, as soon as

regardless if you have a selection or not,

00:26:27.870 --> 00:26:30.450
As long as you know that it does,

00:26:30.450 --> 00:26:34.688
Cuz, the Draw Borders, I'm just gonna

00:26:34.688 --> 00:26:38.410
the Draw Borders can be kinda fun,

00:26:38.410 --> 00:26:43.423
Here, I'm going to make this red, now

00:26:43.423 --> 00:26:46.970
So soon as I change the color I'm

00:26:48.500 --> 00:26:53.140
Now what I can do is I can just like
kinda click, hold, and drag, and

00:26:53.140 --> 00:26:57.370
I can apply the borders

497
00:26:57.370 --> 00:26:59.750
So you're drawing a border.

498
00:27:01.330 --> 00:27:03.710
You're kinda like [NOISE], I know, me too.

00:27:03.710 --> 00:27:07.420
I will tell you I don't do this a lot,
but I know what it does, so

00:27:07.420 --> 00:27:09.110
every once in a while I will.

00:27:09.110 --> 00:27:13.150
Because if I wanted to start getting a
little fancy and then come over here, and
