00:27:13.150 --> 00:27:15.370
now let's go ahead and change the color.

503
00:27:15.370 --> 00:27:17.688
And now let's go ahead and

[LAUGH] But notice I also can do

take it for what it is.

00:27:26.225 --> 00:27:30.100
So see whether or not you want to do it,

00:27:30.100 --> 00:27:34.002
But do know that now my Draw Border is on,

00:27:34.002 --> 00:27:36.089
you got to turn it off, okay?

510
00:27:36.089 --> 00:27:40.784
The same way, let me just scroll down

00:27:40.784 --> 00:27:42.789

00:27:42.789 --> 00:27:44.430
It's gonna draw a grid, okay.

00:27:44.430 --> 00:27:48.760
[LAUGH] So it's basically

00:27:48.760 --> 00:27:54.070

00:27:54.070 --> 00:27:57.595
You know we were talking about slapping

00:27:57.595 --> 00:27:58.850
[LAUGH] So I can take that,

the same things happens if

It's like, you turn it on,

00:28:05.270 --> 00:28:09.630

00:28:09.630 --> 00:28:12.220
Let me click, hold, and

So it's a little bit more freehand if

Border Grid, and the Erase.

And you gotta know to turn them off,

Now the other thing of being able to have

Let me show you,

And if you choose all these

Look at where you are at,

00:28:50.250 --> 00:28:53.640
This is another one that

00:28:56.860 --> 00:29:02.425
So I have over here, you see that we've

Top, middle, bottom,

00:29:06.210 --> 00:29:07.150
If I choose outside,

it's all the outsides,
if I click insides, its all the insides.

00:29:10.490 --> 00:29:15.140
I can turn off the outsides, well actually
now it's like I only want the insides and

00:29:16.410 --> 00:29:19.940
Then you see you can turn

00:29:23.770 --> 00:29:25.690
That's a little too much so

00:29:25.690 --> 00:29:29.225

00:29:29.225 --> 00:29:32.220
[LAUGH] Here's all my borders but

But then I'm like, okay so

00:29:38.576 --> 00:29:43.683

00:30:09.670 --> 00:30:13.710
Now this is the other one, if I choose
None, let me just clear it, watch this.

If I click this one, in between,

00:30:18.161 --> 00:30:22.630

That's how you do it, you have to go

So style, color, come on [LAUGH],

So then that's what I get here,

It's kind of like null does not

00:32:22.000 --> 00:32:27.370
So it's a little weird, but I know we're

I love me some styles,

00:32:49.690 --> 00:32:51.700
I have an absolute mess on my screen.

00:32:51.700 --> 00:32:55.030
So I just kinda want to clear things out.

597
00:32:55.030 --> 00:32:59.640
Well I tried and I failed horribly, so
luckily we're coming back talk about that,

598
00:32:59.640 --> 00:33:00.950

599
00:33:00.950 --> 00:33:02.570
But for now we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

600
00:33:02.570 --> 00:33:05.360
So signing off for OfficeProTV I've
been your host, Justin Dennison.

601
00:33:05.360 --> 00:33:06.070
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

602
00:33:06.070 --> 00:33:08.092
>> And we'ill see you next time.

603
00:33:08.092 --> 00:33:13.409
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Justin and Vonne continue to discuss cell formatting, specifically covering cell styles.  They show how to apply styles, modify and update styles, and create custom styles.  They also demonstrate how themes are connected to styles and the overall formatting of a workbook.
episodes.title: Styles and Themes

WEBVTT

those applied, those applied.

514
00:25:50.400 --> 00:25:52.360
I just changed all of those.

515
00:25:52.360 --> 00:25:56.010
With one place because I used styles,
okay?

516
00:25:56.010 --> 00:25:57.100
So back to that format painter.

517
00:25:57.100 --> 00:26:00.720
Wouldn't this be a lot easier than
changing them all on my own manually?

518
00:26:00.720 --> 00:26:02.080
>> This is substantially easier.

519
00:26:02.080 --> 00:26:06.120
And also once you get everything
kind of relatively styled.

520
00:26:06.120 --> 00:26:07.840
What I mean, this is a heading one,

521
00:26:07.840 --> 00:26:11.090
this is heading two,
these are subheadings and totals.

522
00:26:11.090 --> 00:26:14.120
Then you can kinda tweak but
this does beg the question.

523
00:26:14.120 --> 00:26:17.890
We changed the style for a selected theme,
did we modify the theme across all

524
00:26:17.890 --> 00:26:21.580
the other ones or
did we just do it for this workbook?

525
00:26:21.580 --> 00:26:23.730
Or did it create a custom one for us?

526
00:26:23.730 --> 00:26:26.570
>> Okay, good question, it's only for
this workbook and only for

527
00:26:26.570 --> 00:26:28.030
that particular style, okay?

528
00:26:28.030 --> 00:26:29.480
First is the heading two.

529
00:26:29.480 --> 00:26:31.080
We didn't mess with heading one or
heading two.

530
00:26:31.080 --> 00:26:34.790
So, and if I started a new,
I'm just doing Cmd+N, right?

531
00:26:34.790 --> 00:26:38.340
And I'm using that same,
I think we're on Madison or whatever.

532
00:26:38.340 --> 00:26:41.060
It's not going to affect those.

533
00:26:41.060 --> 00:26:44.840
Okay, so
Madison back over here to the heading two.

534
00:26:44.840 --> 00:26:46.310
Notice it's back to it's default.

535
00:26:46.310 --> 00:26:48.750
So yes, workbook specific.

536
00:26:48.750 --> 00:26:53.582
I don't need to save my
changes to that one.

537
00:26:53.582 --> 00:26:54.460
Take note though.

538
00:26:54.460 --> 00:26:56.080
Look at this one.

539
00:26:56.080 --> 00:26:57.100
That's still pink, isn't it?

540
00:26:57.100 --> 00:27:01.190
That's the same font
why didn't that choose?

541
00:27:01.190 --> 00:27:03.064
You know about styles what is this?

542
00:27:03.064 --> 00:27:06.820
>> I think we did not apply the style
using that selection we just kind of hard

543
00:27:06.820 --> 00:27:11.190
coded that to make it look like the ones
that were previously there, right?

544
00:27:11.190 --> 00:27:16.650
>> Local overrides,
it's like inline styles overriding, yes,

545
00:27:16.650 --> 00:27:20.490
I'm talking code, but when I talk
about format and local overrides,

546
00:27:20.490 --> 00:27:24.070
I came into here and
physically changed this to pin.

547
00:27:24.070 --> 00:27:29.470
Anything that you're doing at a local
level, like I selected these cells,

548
00:27:29.470 --> 00:27:33.880
that's going to override any
styles that I've applied.

549
00:27:33.880 --> 00:27:38.550
Styles are more like up here like in the
global, this is local applied formatting.

550
00:27:38.550 --> 00:27:43.110
Locally applied formatting
will always win the globals.

551
00:27:43.110 --> 00:27:47.460
And we're talking CSS-stuff about
style sheets and inline styles,

552
00:27:47.460 --> 00:27:51.880
override embedded styles, and
embedded styles override global styles.

553
00:27:53.040 --> 00:27:55.353
It's just a layer of who wins.

554
00:27:55.353 --> 00:27:59.860
What definition wins out,
and so be careful.

555
00:27:59.860 --> 00:28:03.620
That's why I said if you apply a style,
do not come in and go ahead and

556
00:28:03.620 --> 00:28:06.490
go other tweakings at the cell level.

557
00:28:06.490 --> 00:28:09.010
Do it at the style level.

558
00:28:09.010 --> 00:28:11.360
Because otherwise it's
not going to go through.

559
00:28:11.360 --> 00:28:14.690
Now, the cool thing I was like, well if I
really want this to look like the rest of

560
00:28:14.690 --> 00:28:20.110
them, you just select the text and
then just apply the style again, okay.

561
00:28:20.110 --> 00:28:23.420
So that's where you go in and
modify it and it's cool.

562
00:28:24.970 --> 00:28:27.530
Coming back over here to our.

563
00:28:27.530 --> 00:28:28.080
Did I get rid?

564
00:28:28.080 --> 00:28:29.124
No, it's address.

565
00:28:29.124 --> 00:28:30.870
There we go.
I'm like, where's pumpkin?

566
00:28:30.870 --> 00:28:33.110
Okay, well, pumpkin's gone.

567
00:28:33.110 --> 00:28:36.875
But pumpkin right here,
if I like this, the comic-sans,

568
00:28:36.875 --> 00:28:40.281
the 16, all of the alignment stuff,
everything.

569
00:28:40.281 --> 00:28:42.290
I want this to my own style.

570
00:28:42.290 --> 00:28:45.270
If they already have premade
styles who can I make my own?

571
00:28:45.270 --> 00:28:46.180
Yes, you can.

572
00:28:46.180 --> 00:28:50.104
The cool thing is, you go ahead and
format a cell and you really like this and

573
00:28:50.104 --> 00:28:52.551
you want to move it all over the place,
right?

574
00:28:52.551 --> 00:28:57.020
Kinda going back to,
I'm going back way too far.

575
00:28:57.020 --> 00:29:00.540
Okay, kinda going back to here where
all of these are just regular.

576
00:29:02.400 --> 00:29:04.150
Let's go ahead and
clear the formats like that.

577
00:29:04.150 --> 00:29:10.060
I'd be a lot easier if I took
this made my own style, right?

578
00:29:10.060 --> 00:29:13.375
Do my formats first, come in a new
cell style, checking to make sure,

579
00:29:13.375 --> 00:29:16.430
now notice do I really wanna apply
the number formats and align.

580
00:29:16.430 --> 00:29:21.130
It's taking everything,
I'll go with it, that's fine.

581
00:29:21.130 --> 00:29:23.940
And then I just go ahead and
name this pumpkin, okay.

582
00:29:23.940 --> 00:29:28.810
And I click OK, I now have my own style.

583
00:29:28.810 --> 00:29:33.010
So if I come over here and use my control
key, or sorry, my command key, and

584
00:29:33.010 --> 00:29:39.100
I get all of these, and then say,
hey, let's all be a pumpkin.

585
00:29:39.100 --> 00:29:41.520
And there you go,
that to me it's a little easier.

586
00:29:41.520 --> 00:29:45.060
Cuz then you know,
you need to make that a little different.

587
00:29:45.060 --> 00:29:47.260
You modify it, you change the font.

588
00:29:47.260 --> 00:29:48.190
I'm going a little fast.

589
00:29:48.190 --> 00:29:53.477
So if I'm clicking a little too fast,
just stay with me for visual purposes.

590
00:29:53.477 --> 00:29:55.480
I'll make this pink, okay?

591
00:29:55.480 --> 00:29:56.266
Click OK.

592
00:29:56.266 --> 00:29:57.770
Turn that back on, perfect.

593
00:29:57.770 --> 00:29:59.800
So click OK, and then all of them change.

594
00:29:59.800 --> 00:30:02.610
This one didn't change because you
actually never applied the style to it,

595
00:30:02.610 --> 00:30:04.960
you know how that is when you
do CSS style definitions.

596
00:30:04.960 --> 00:30:08.520
So I would just come back and
there you go.

597
00:30:08.520 --> 00:30:12.320
I love styles, they're so much fun,
they can save you so much time.

598
00:30:12.320 --> 00:30:15.190
Especially if you have
a lot of worksheets but

599
00:30:15.190 --> 00:30:17.240
you're making everything look the same.

600
00:30:17.240 --> 00:30:20.220
Someone comes along and
needs you to change it.

601
00:30:20.220 --> 00:30:22.040
It's gonna hurt if you don't have styles.

602
00:30:22.040 --> 00:30:25.460
So knowing how they working,
knowing they're connected to themes.

603
00:30:25.460 --> 00:30:29.910
Now you know how to change your
theme colors over in PowerPoint, but

604
00:30:29.910 --> 00:30:30.600
that's what you got.

605
00:30:30.600 --> 00:30:33.470
So lots of fun, have a good time with it.

606
00:30:33.470 --> 00:30:37.549
>> Von, that's definitely gonna make you
more productive as you try to try out

607
00:30:37.549 --> 00:30:38.280
things.

608
00:30:38.280 --> 00:30:40.390
Maybe it's some for fun, some for

609
00:30:40.390 --> 00:30:45.320
business but you don't wanna be formatting
kind of with that paint brush all of the.

610
00:30:45.320 --> 00:30:48.613
If you've ever painted an entire
wall with a two inch paintbrush you

611
00:30:48.613 --> 00:30:49.667
know that's no fun.

612
00:30:49.667 --> 00:30:53.490
Just remember, the closer
the style is to the thing, right?

613
00:30:53.490 --> 00:30:54.610
It's kind of like a person,

614
00:30:54.610 --> 00:30:57.760
the people closest to you
have the most effect on you.

615
00:30:57.760 --> 00:31:00.160
Peoples furthest away have
the least affect on you.

616
00:31:00.160 --> 00:31:01.410
And that's how styles work.

617
00:31:01.410 --> 00:31:03.312
Thank you so much Von and
thank you for joining us.

618
00:31:03.312 --> 00:31:04.820
We're gonna go ahead and get out of here.

619
00:31:04.820 --> 00:31:07.520
So signing off for Office Pro TV,
I've been your host Justin Ennis.

620
00:31:07.520 --> 00:31:12.130
>> And I'm Von Smith.
>> And we'll see you next time.

621
00:31:12.130 --> 00:31:17.797
[SOUND]

episodes.description: Vonne and Justin start a small mini series on number formats.  In this episode, they introduce number formats and discuss the difference between inputted data vs displayed data.
episodes.title: Number Formats: Introduction
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.584 --> 00:00:15.506
Greetings everyone, and welcome back to
another exciting episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:15.506 --> 00:00:17.425
I'm your host, Justin Dennison, and

4
00:00:17.425 --> 00:00:21.041
we're continuing on with our Excel
2016 Essentials for Mac series.

5
00:00:21.041 --> 00:00:24.060
And what we're gonna be talking about,
number formats.

6
00:00:24.060 --> 00:00:29.320
I know, you're like I don't know,
trust me, they are very useful and well,

7
00:00:29.320 --> 00:00:32.020
if you wanna be taken seriously you're
definitely gonna need to know about them.

8
00:00:32.020 --> 00:00:35.470
Luckily we have someone in the studio who
knows all about them, Ms. Vonne Smith.

9
00:00:35.470 --> 00:00:37.958
How you doing today Vonne?
>> I'm doing fantastic, how you doing?

10
00:00:37.958 --> 00:00:39.632
>> I am doing fantastic Vonne.

11
00:00:39.632 --> 00:00:44.679
Now number formats, it seems simple but
you and I have talked, outside

12
00:00:44.679 --> 00:00:50.250
of the show, there's actually a lot more
to them than one would first assume.

13
00:00:50.250 --> 00:00:52.910
So what do we need to know
actually to get our feet wet

14
00:00:52.910 --> 00:00:53.740
here?
>> Yeah,

15
00:00:53.740 --> 00:00:58.530
it's a very important part of Excel,
and once you get the hang of it,

16
00:00:58.530 --> 00:01:00.990
it seems pretty straightforward, but

17
00:01:00.990 --> 00:01:06.260
I've watched newbies to Excel trip
up on this time and time again.

18
00:01:06.260 --> 00:01:09.020
I trip up on it from time to time as well.

19
00:01:09.020 --> 00:01:12.865
So it's a very big topic,
a very important topic, so

20
00:01:12.865 --> 00:01:16.830
what I've decided to do is
kind of break it on down.

21
00:01:16.830 --> 00:01:19.810
We're gonna break it down into
a little mini series as I call it.

22
00:01:19.810 --> 00:01:23.640
So we have a couple different episodes
that are going through all the different

23
00:01:23.640 --> 00:01:25.590
types of number formats and show examples.

24
00:01:25.590 --> 00:01:30.070
We can talk a little bit about it, but
this first one is really just, well,

25
00:01:30.070 --> 00:01:34.050
introducing the concept of
what is a number format.

26
00:01:34.050 --> 00:01:38.970
We just did our episodes about cell
formats like changing the font,

27
00:01:38.970 --> 00:01:43.450
and changing the font size, and the color,
and the border, and the shading.

28
00:01:43.450 --> 00:01:44.720
And what were we doing?

29
00:01:44.720 --> 00:01:46.738
We're changing the way something looks,
right?

30
00:01:46.738 --> 00:01:54.860
I want the Comic Sans or Curlz MT font
because it gives a certain meaning.

31
00:01:54.860 --> 00:01:57.870
Using Comic Sans verses Courier,

32
00:01:57.870 --> 00:02:02.820
two totally different feels of how
we're presenting the information.

33
00:02:02.820 --> 00:02:05.330
Well, the same is true with numbers.

34
00:02:05.330 --> 00:02:09.830
But when you get into the world of
numbers, then you think of math and

35
00:02:09.830 --> 00:02:13.910
how it's displayed and then, gosh, I'm so
glad you're here with me today, Justin.

36
00:02:13.910 --> 00:02:18.835
Because I know math and science and
all that is near and dear to your heart.

37
00:02:18.835 --> 00:02:19.633
>> It is, it is,

38
00:02:19.633 --> 00:02:23.385
it was one of my first passions,
obviously along with computing.

39
00:02:23.385 --> 00:02:25.893
But numbers are important because,
you know,

40
00:02:25.893 --> 00:02:28.286
when someone is like I'm gonna pay you 50.

41
00:02:28.286 --> 00:02:28.833
50 what?

42
00:02:28.833 --> 00:02:34.941
$50, $0.50, 50 pesos, those units are
definitely important when you're trying

43
00:02:34.941 --> 00:02:38.081
to convey information appropriately.
>> Yeah,

44
00:02:38.081 --> 00:02:39.402
maybe $50 million?
>> [LAUGH]

45
00:02:39.402 --> 00:02:40.413
>> That would be awesome!

46
00:02:40.413 --> 00:02:42.480
[LAUGH] I would like that.

47
00:02:42.480 --> 00:02:47.940
Yeah, so exactly, it's very important to,
like what are we actually displaying?

48
00:02:47.940 --> 00:02:51.060
And let's start there, so
we have an idea of okay,

49
00:02:51.060 --> 00:02:55.720
what do I want my numbers to say,
how I want them displayed?

50
00:02:55.720 --> 00:02:56.850
And we also have to think about like,

51
00:02:56.850 --> 00:03:00.205
how am I going to be
inputting the data into it?

52
00:03:00.205 --> 00:03:04.450
So introduction to number formats,
why don't we go ahead and jump down to my

53
00:03:04.450 --> 00:03:08.790
screen cuz we always need visuals to go
ahead and demonstrate our concepts here.

54
00:03:08.790 --> 00:03:13.606
All right, so
what I have here is just some examples of,

55
00:03:13.606 --> 00:03:20.376
it's gonna kind of exemplify the input,
how I typed it, versus the display.

56
00:03:20.376 --> 00:03:24.696
Versus like well, you could have
something be inputted the same way but

57
00:03:24.696 --> 00:03:26.570
not displayed the same.

58
00:03:26.570 --> 00:03:28.962
I just did a total couple
circles right there.

59
00:03:28.962 --> 00:03:32.680
[LAUGH] So
why don't I zoom in a little bit here.

60
00:03:32.680 --> 00:03:37.810
And so right here, the boxes that I
have on the left are column B, and

61
00:03:37.810 --> 00:03:41.040
then column D, they're actually the same.

62
00:03:41.040 --> 00:03:48.255
This is the same as this, and
you're like, [LAUGH] no it's not.

63
00:03:48.255 --> 00:03:51.749
It is, okay?
And that was a whole 2,500, what?

64
00:03:51.749 --> 00:03:56.990
Dollars, cats,
I mean what are we talking about here?

65
00:03:56.990 --> 00:04:00.590
Is this just a number or
is this actually like a monetary value?

66
00:04:00.590 --> 00:04:04.270
How do I know that this is $2500,
like what

67
00:04:04.270 --> 00:04:07.800
would indicate that to you there Justin?
>> Well we have the currency symbol there

68
00:04:07.800 --> 00:04:12.170
and this is US dollars, so we have
the currency symbol for US dollars.

69
00:04:12.170 --> 00:04:16.069
On the left hand side is 2,500 and
as you said it could be 2,500 cats,

70
00:04:16.069 --> 00:04:20.324
you're probably gonna need a lot more
than $2500 if you have 2,500 cats but

71
00:04:20.324 --> 00:04:22.820
maybe that's best spent on another time.
>> [LAUGH]

72
00:04:22.820 --> 00:04:25.460
>> The units here are very

73
00:04:25.460 --> 00:04:28.510
indicative of your intentions.
>> Yeah definitely, and

74
00:04:28.510 --> 00:04:33.780
even the next one right here,
like the decimal point.

75
00:04:33.780 --> 00:04:39.162
How important is that decimal point
in how we're measuring things?

76
00:04:39.162 --> 00:04:41.368
I mean and that's where,
do we measure it in whole?

77
00:04:41.368 --> 00:04:44.630
Like this, and these are two completely
different numbers aren't they?

78
00:04:44.630 --> 00:04:48.310
Because of where the decimal place is,
and where is that comma,

79
00:04:48.310 --> 00:04:49.530
so I can tell that this is $12,000.

80
00:04:49.530 --> 00:04:52.870
So you can already get the idea, so

81
00:04:52.870 --> 00:04:55.160
many different ways that
we can display a number.

82
00:04:55.160 --> 00:04:56.238
How about this next one?

83
00:04:56.238 --> 00:04:58.651
2, versus 1.568921.

84
00:04:58.651 --> 00:05:04.545
Yeah, but I mean if we're talking
about the rules of rounding,

85
00:05:04.545 --> 00:05:11.652
1.56 is rounded up to the nearest
whole decimal, and that's 2, okay?

86
00:05:11.652 --> 00:05:14.590
But again, what are we measuring?

87
00:05:14.590 --> 00:05:16.510
Do we need this many decimal places?

88
00:05:16.510 --> 00:05:17.960
Do we need to round up?

89
00:05:17.960 --> 00:05:21.986
It's a big deal when you're
displaying data and numbers, okay and

90
00:05:21.986 --> 00:05:24.761
enough of course my favorite fractions,
right?

91
00:05:24.761 --> 00:05:28.610
Whoo-hoo, yeah decimals and fractions,
and I do a pretty good job.

92
00:05:28.610 --> 00:05:31.842
But then if you, I think about you know,
our fourth and fifth grade math,

93
00:05:31.842 --> 00:05:34.816
I'm like if I was given like a fifth
grade math test after right now,

94
00:05:34.816 --> 00:05:36.525
I don't know [LAUGH] if I could do that.

95
00:05:36.525 --> 00:05:41.187
Convert fractions and all like kind of
stuff, and you flip it and times, whoo,

96
00:05:41.187 --> 00:05:43.891
yeah, [LAUGH] kind of scary.
>> Well it's not scary to me,

97
00:05:43.891 --> 00:05:45.781
I would crush it.
>> [LAUGH]

98
00:05:45.781 --> 00:05:46.776
>> I hope I would crush,

99
00:05:46.776 --> 00:05:50.482
you never know though, and math does
change and what's taught at the fourth and

100
00:05:50.482 --> 00:05:54.490
fifth grade level maybe there's things
that I've forgotten so who's knows there.

101
00:05:54.490 --> 00:05:58.617
But I do wanna bring up a key point,
not only does it help with our intentions,

102
00:05:58.617 --> 00:06:00.279
what we're trying to convey.

103
00:06:00.279 --> 00:06:04.080
It also helps with readability
to some capacity, right?

104
00:06:04.080 --> 00:06:07.173
You're like well is it 1.568921?

105
00:06:07.173 --> 00:06:10.512
Well, if you're talking about taxes
I know when I input my taxes,

106
00:06:10.512 --> 00:06:14.446
you actually get a round up or round up or
a round down based on the penny amount,

107
00:06:14.446 --> 00:06:16.857
because they care about
whole dollar amounts.

108
00:06:16.857 --> 00:06:21.465
And well if you're doing a tax sheet,
rounding may be applicable to you and

109
00:06:21.465 --> 00:06:25.635
it allows you to get a quick glance
of the monetary amounts without,

110
00:06:25.635 --> 00:06:28.290
well there's 13 decimals places here.

111
00:06:28.290 --> 00:06:32.000
What am I supposed to do, right?
>> Yeah and talking about taxes,

112
00:06:32.000 --> 00:06:32.850
I haven't done mine yet.

113
00:06:32.850 --> 00:06:34.648
Oops, got a month, right.

114
00:06:34.648 --> 00:06:37.040
[LAUGH] It's a, yeah, bad subject.

115
00:06:37.040 --> 00:06:41.448
[LAUGH] But anyways, yeah,
that's a great example though of when and

116
00:06:41.448 --> 00:06:43.510

So if I took that and then okay.

469
00:28:31.974 --> 00:28:36.310
But it's just saying you could have
a number there, but it's kind of implied,

470
00:28:36.310 --> 00:28:40.110
too, it's just saying that
last one has to be a zero.

471
00:28:40.110 --> 00:28:43.470
So that's the biggest thing,
and you can see some of them,

472
00:28:43.470 --> 00:28:46.580
it's almost like with the currency codes.

473
00:28:46.580 --> 00:28:49.040
Okay, that last one could be a zero, but

474
00:28:49.040 --> 00:28:52.360
the rest of them could all be numbers.
>> What if I typed 00 now in this?

475
00:28:52.360 --> 00:28:56.230
Would it remove the zeros,
so I get a single zero.

476
00:28:56.230 --> 00:29:00.860
If I take that off, if I take off
the pound sign in that custom formatting,

477
00:29:00.860 --> 00:29:03.590
does it still just
default to a single zero?

478
00:29:03.590 --> 00:29:09.110
Or does it now allow me to type 00?
>> It's still gonna drop it,

479
00:29:09.110 --> 00:29:14.100
because if I needed it to be zero in
the front, I would have to do 00.

480
00:29:14.100 --> 00:29:17.770
But that's another one that
gets a little weird too, okay?

481
00:29:17.770 --> 00:29:22.400
So let's go back to I want two of them,
right?

482
00:29:22.400 --> 00:29:26.280
So now, all of those, say anything.

483
00:29:26.280 --> 00:29:28.010
If I typed in 1, it's 01.

484
00:29:28.010 --> 00:29:33.440
If I type in 6,
it's gonna force it to have it.

485
00:29:33.440 --> 00:29:35.620
Cuz you're saying,
this is a placeholder, and

486
00:29:35.620 --> 00:29:37.890
it will always show a 0 in front of it.

487
00:29:37.890 --> 00:29:43.090
So that's where the, if you don't know if
it's gonna have numbers in front of it.

488
00:29:43.090 --> 00:29:47.920
It could be a 1000 degrees, it could
be 100 degrees, it could be 0 degrees.

489
00:29:47.920 --> 00:29:55.120
You only want the zero on that last
placeholder, like in the ones holder,

490
00:29:55.120 --> 00:29:58.840
that's where you want the zero, not in
the tens or the hundreds or what have you.

491
00:29:58.840 --> 00:30:00.370
It takes a little bit of getting used to.

492
00:30:00.370 --> 00:30:05.130
I mean you do have to play around with it,
you can go pretty far in-depth with this.

493
00:30:05.130 --> 00:30:08.460
But it's the same conventions
that are through here,

494
00:30:08.460 --> 00:30:11.830
and that's why I brought up the Help file
if you want a little bit more information.

495
00:30:11.830 --> 00:30:13.430
How is it gonna treat
your negative numbers?

496
00:30:13.430 --> 00:30:17.120
How is it gonna treat your zero values,
all of that.

497
00:30:17.120 --> 00:30:23.390
But the quotes for the text, the pound for
the number, or the number for the number

498
00:30:23.390 --> 00:30:28.530
and zero for, you need to accept a zero
value in that particular placeholder.

499
00:30:28.530 --> 00:30:29.630
So, could be fun.

500
00:30:29.630 --> 00:30:34.000
Lot of good stuff, I like it for
these things, and then the text for

501
00:30:34.000 --> 00:30:35.560
my section numbers.

502
00:30:35.560 --> 00:30:38.140
And the custom or the special for
like the phone numbers.

503
00:30:38.140 --> 00:30:41.970
A lot of good things cuz we're not
always storing numbers as numbers.

504
00:30:41.970 --> 00:30:45.050
It could be different values and

505
00:30:45.050 --> 00:30:47.360
connotations apply to them.
>> Well Vonne,

506
00:30:47.360 --> 00:30:51.240
you've definitely opened my eyes to custom
number formats because I can't tell you

507
00:30:51.240 --> 00:30:56.130
how many times I've spent a ridiculous
amount of time adding parentheses or

508
00:30:56.130 --> 00:30:58.560
copying and pasting the degree symbol.

509
00:30:58.560 --> 00:31:02.590
So thank you so much for that, and I know
we got dates and times coming up, and

510
00:31:02.590 --> 00:31:04.860
well if you're ready for it,
then definitely come on back.

511
00:31:04.860 --> 00:31:06.470
But for now we're going to go ahead and
get out of here.

512
00:31:06.470 --> 00:31:09.220
So signing off for OfficeProTV,
I've been your host Justin Dennis.

513
00:31:09.220 --> 00:31:10.020
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

514
00:31:10.020 --> 00:31:12.464
>> And we'll see you next time.

515
00:31:12.464 --> 00:31:13.700
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Justin and Vonne finish the number format mini series by discussing date and time number formats. They also introduce the DATEVALUE function.
episodes.title: Number Formats: Date and Time
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.473 --> 00:00:15.474
Greetings everyone and welcome back to
another exciting episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:15.474 --> 00:00:17.031
I'm your host Justin Dennison and

4
00:00:17.031 --> 00:00:19.671
we're back with more Excel
2016 essentials for Mac.

5
00:00:19.671 --> 00:00:22.351
And well,
we're continuing on in number formats.

6
00:00:22.351 --> 00:00:25.330
We're up to our eyeballs
in number formats and well,

7
00:00:25.330 --> 00:00:28.190
we're gonna talk about dates and
times today.

8
00:00:28.190 --> 00:00:32.270
It's funny because they sound simple,
but yet, they are not.

9
00:00:32.270 --> 00:00:37.095
And here to help us kind of reveal how
not simple they are, Ms. Vonne Smith.

10
00:00:37.095 --> 00:00:38.125
How are you doing today, Vonne?

11
00:00:38.125 --> 00:00:39.175
I'm doing pretty good.

12
00:00:39.175 --> 00:00:42.620
Yeah, we are up to our eyeballs
in number formats, yeah.

13
00:00:42.620 --> 00:00:45.335
And my eyes feel like they're
starting to close a little bit.

14
00:00:45.335 --> 00:00:51.265
Hopefully yours aren't and, we're keeping
you awake enough for, yes, date and times.

15
00:00:51.265 --> 00:00:56.120
Whew, yeah, we should probably
start off by talking about

16
00:00:56.120 --> 00:01:01.400
the world date formats,
and there's so many ways.

17
00:01:01.400 --> 00:01:07.680
So if I told you, Justin,
how would you normally say what today is?

18
00:01:07.680 --> 00:01:11.069
Well, I would give it to
you as a month-day-year, so

19
00:01:11.069 --> 00:01:14.475
like March 18th, 2018 or
something like that.

20
00:01:14.475 --> 00:01:15.979
It's the 12th right now, but close enough.

21
00:01:15.979 --> 00:01:18.830
[LAUGH] Tomato tomato,
Vonne, tomato tomato.

22
00:01:18.830 --> 00:01:22.450
[LAUGH] I know, I'm like is he gonna look
down at his computer to look at the little

23
00:01:22.450 --> 00:01:23.342
calendar icon?

24
00:01:23.342 --> 00:01:25.783
[LAUGH] No, I took a shot, and
then you made me feel bad about it.

25
00:01:25.783 --> 00:01:27.355
[LAUGH] [LAUGH] That's what I'm here for.

26
00:01:27.355 --> 00:01:29.830
[LAUGH] So, but yes, exactly.

27
00:01:29.830 --> 00:01:35.610
Here in America, that we go ahead and
say that yeah, it is March 12th, 2018.

28
00:01:35.610 --> 00:01:43.520
And we put the comma after the day,
and that's how we display our dates.

29
00:01:43.520 --> 00:01:47.480
Okay, great, that's if we're talking and
we're writing it,

30
00:01:47.480 --> 00:01:49.718
we could call it, longhand, okay?

31
00:01:49.718 --> 00:01:54.717
But then what are some common separators
that we can have between those month,

32
00:01:54.717 --> 00:01:56.275
days and years?

33
00:01:56.275 --> 00:01:59.869
So I've seen slashes, back slash?

34
00:01:59.869 --> 00:02:00.655
Forward slash?

35
00:02:00.655 --> 00:02:01.695
Forward slash.
I don't know.

36
00:02:01.695 --> 00:02:02.865
One of those slashes.

37
00:02:02.865 --> 00:02:05.635
Let me look at my keyboard,
I'm pretty sure it's a forward slash.

38
00:02:05.635 --> 00:02:08.285
So month, day, year with forward slashes.

39
00:02:08.285 --> 00:02:12.945
Along with those, I can sometimes have
a two digit year, or a four digit year.

40
00:02:12.945 --> 00:02:17.760
To remove ambiguity, I try to adopt
a four digit year at all times.

41
00:02:17.760 --> 00:02:21.780
And I've also seen dashes,
so that's always fun.

42
00:02:21.780 --> 00:02:23.560
And the same applies for the year.

43
00:02:23.560 --> 00:02:29.060
Also seen zero padded months, zero padded
days, non-zero padded months and days.

44
00:02:29.060 --> 00:02:33.105
And yes, those seem like nuances,
but they can lead to ambiguity,

45
00:02:33.105 --> 00:02:37.720
not only with the separator, but
the respective numbers that we report.

46
00:02:37.720 --> 00:02:40.400
And sometimes I get a little bit twisted

47
00:02:40.400 --> 00:02:42.650
in trying to realize what
date I'm talking about.

48
00:02:42.650 --> 00:02:47.450
Yeah, exactly and
that's how the countries of

49
00:02:47.450 --> 00:02:52.680
the world format dates,
that can get a little weird.

50
00:02:52.680 --> 00:02:56.720
So I actually have some,
a Wikipedia article pulled up, so

51
00:02:56.720 --> 00:03:00.900
why don't we go ahead and look at this,
in this date format by country.

52
00:03:00.900 --> 00:03:05.040
And so you can see that we have,
I think typically though, y for

53
00:03:05.040 --> 00:03:07.400
year, m for month, d for day.

54
00:03:07.400 --> 00:03:09.940
But then, how do you go ahead and

55
00:03:09.940 --> 00:03:14.320
put them, the two, the four,
you know, all these different things.

56
00:03:14.320 --> 00:03:19.890
And do you do slashes,or the stroke
that they're saying here, the dot.

57
00:03:19.890 --> 00:03:23.370
You could separate by dots,
hyphens, or dashes, or spaces.

58
00:03:23.370 --> 00:03:26.280
Okay, and then I [LAUGH],
I thought this was a fun one.

59
00:03:26.280 --> 00:03:28.410
So it's like the different colors, right?

60
00:03:28.410 --> 00:03:32.730
And then look at so many blue or cyan, and
then yep, we're over here in magenta just

61
00:03:32.730 --> 00:03:36.590
hanging out by ourselves, like always,
having to do different things.

62
00:03:36.590 --> 00:03:39.720
But you can see Canada's off
in its own little world too.

63
00:03:39.720 --> 00:03:41.540
So hey, we're not alone.

64
00:03:41.540 --> 00:03:46.060
But anyways, you can see that,
like how it goes ahead and

65
00:03:46.060 --> 00:03:50.800
formats, and then we have that short
format, we have the long format, and

66
00:03:50.800 --> 00:03:53.620
then all the different ways that
it's going to go ahead and do this.

67
00:03:53.620 --> 00:03:58.010
And it's kinda fun to where we do month,
day, year, right?

68
00:03:58.010 --> 00:04:01.101
And then it's just kind
of like all of this,

69
00:04:01.101 --> 00:04:05.620
and then it goes to like a whole
bunch of nos, no, no, no, no.

70
00:04:05.620 --> 00:04:06.550
Okay, so yeah,

71
00:04:06.550 --> 00:04:10.580
hopefully I didn't just like give you
motion sickness by going so fast.

72
00:04:10.580 --> 00:04:13.560
But there's so many different
ways that we can do this, and

73
00:04:13.560 --> 00:04:15.610
how our separators come out.

74
00:04:15.610 --> 00:04:20.450
And what it's doing to do for
you, you have to know your data,

75
00:04:20.450 --> 00:04:23.630
you need to know how
you want to display it.

76
00:04:23.630 --> 00:04:24.790
And then once you do,

77
00:04:24.790 --> 00:04:29.770
once you decide that big factor, then
you gotta know how to make Excel do it.

78
00:04:29.770 --> 00:04:34.880
So and
it can get you tripped up pretty quickly.

79
00:04:34.880 --> 00:04:36.170
So back here,

80
00:04:36.170 --> 00:04:40.330
we did talk about this in the introduction
about how in the general number format,

81
00:04:40.330 --> 00:04:43.920
let me switch back over here to my home
tab so we can see our number format there.

82
00:04:45.140 --> 00:04:51.030
If I typed in, let's go 1-1-01, okay?

83
00:04:51.030 --> 00:04:59.300
That is January 1st, but
is it 2001, or is it 1901, right?

84
00:04:59.300 --> 00:05:01.120
So which one is it?

85
00:05:01.120 --> 00:05:04.510
Well it went ahead and
defaulted to the 2001,

86
00:05:04.510 --> 00:05:08.190
something you need to be careful
about when you're doing your dates.

87
00:05:08.190 --> 00:05:14.530
And I did type in dashes, and it turned it
to slashes, and that is the forward slash.

88
00:05:14.530 --> 00:05:22.499
So if I type in 06/06/12, right?

89
00:05:22.499 --> 00:05:26.186
That's a date, so that's June, right?

90
00:05:26.186 --> 00:05:30.110
[LAUGH] June 6th, 2012.

91
00:05:30.110 --> 00:05:32.001
But it took off the zero, okay?

92
00:05:32.001 --> 00:05:36.231
And if I typed in, let's go 050,

93
00:05:36.231 --> 00:05:40.876
oops, let's go ahead and do with dash.

94
00:05:40.876 --> 00:05:44.843
05-2012, that's what I was trying to do.

95
00:05:44.843 --> 00:05:48.556
Again, it took off those things because
that's where it's doing the automatic

96
00:05:48.556 --> 00:05:49.126
flipping.

97
00:05:49.126 --> 00:05:55.100
But, I preformatted some of our cells,
here, this one is a date.

98
00:05:55.100 --> 00:05:58.674
But, if we typed it in, okay,

99
00:05:58.674 --> 00:06:04.510
12-12-12, well, look what it did.

100
00:06:04.510 --> 00:06:09.264
It's the 12th of December in 2012, okay?

101
00:06:09.264 --> 00:06:12.370
Because I formatted that way.

102
00:06:12.370 --> 00:06:19.524
But all of these are going to be,
and I keep on, we could do 05-05-85.

103
00:06:19.524 --> 00:06:23.143
So now you can see that it's flipping
it because I've already formatted this

104
00:06:23.143 --> 00:06:23.650
as a date.

105
00:06:25.260 --> 00:06:27.920
But you gotta be careful when
you change this to text.

106
00:06:27.920 --> 00:06:33.630
And I'm going to notice that my
cell formatting right now is text,

107
00:06:33.630 --> 00:06:35.340
so if I did 05-05-85.

108
00:06:35.340 --> 00:06:38.763
It's not flipping, is it?

109
00:06:38.763 --> 00:06:39.638
Cuz it's text.

110
00:06:39.638 --> 00:06:43.690
And then if I did 6/6/2000 and

111
00:06:43.690 --> 00:06:48.510
whoops, that's the wrong one, 2012.

112
00:06:48.510 --> 00:06:51.640
Not gonna flip it, okay?

113
00:06:52.660 --> 00:06:56.950
These are are already
talking in date format.

114
00:06:56.950 --> 00:07:01.090
So if I flipped these over, and
let's go ahead and take these,

115
00:07:01.090 --> 00:07:04.030
I'm just going to select these cells,
just these.

116
00:07:04.030 --> 00:07:08.200
And if I come in to date, notice there's
a short date and there is a long date, but

117
00:07:08.200 --> 00:07:14.320
then there are a whole bunch more
ways that I can format dates.

118
00:07:14.320 --> 00:07:15.430
Do I want the day?

119
00:07:15.430 --> 00:07:17.650
Do I want the two digits?

120
00:07:17.650 --> 00:07:18.906
Do I want the three digits?

121
00:07:18.906 --> 00:07:19.920
Three digits?

122
00:07:19.920 --> 00:07:20.780
Four digits?

123
00:07:20.780 --> 00:07:25.400
All of those different ways that I would
want it to be displayed, you can do that.

124
00:07:25.400 --> 00:07:30.730
So if I wanted it to be March 14th,
2012, meaning the example.

125
00:07:30.730 --> 00:07:33.050
Notice up here it is showing it that way.

126
00:07:33.050 --> 00:07:35.710
I click OK, it will flip that way.

127
00:07:36.830 --> 00:07:41.150
If I wanna do it in this way, right?

128
00:07:41.150 --> 00:07:43.400
So then it's gonna flip it over.

129
00:07:43.400 --> 00:07:44.740
But watch if I take these.

130
00:07:44.740 --> 00:07:49.970
Let's go ahead and include these in here,
these cells down here.

131
00:07:49.970 --> 00:07:52.180
And I change this to, let's do short date.

132
00:07:52.180 --> 00:07:54.120
That didn't flip, did it?

133
00:07:55.570 --> 00:08:00.656
If I did the long date,
that didn't flip either.

134
00:08:00.656 --> 00:08:05.941
If you have your cells formatted as text,
and you enter a date,

135
00:08:05.941 --> 00:08:10.650
it will not see it as a date
no matter what you do.

136
00:08:10.650 --> 00:08:15.347
This actually, this happened in one of
our co-workers and a good friend of mine.

137
00:08:15.347 --> 00:08:17.430
And she's like, I don't understand
what's going on with this?

138
00:08:17.430 --> 00:08:21.388
And I'm like, it took me a little bit too,
I'm like wait, hold on.

139
00:08:21.388 --> 00:08:25.350
Somehow those cells
are not seeing as a date,

140
00:08:25.350 --> 00:08:29.000
so you can't go to all these different
formats that I'm showing you how to do it,

141
00:08:29.000 --> 00:08:31.430
because it's never gonna see it that way.

142
00:08:31.430 --> 00:08:34.790
And that's something that you watch it,
okay?

143
00:08:34.790 --> 00:08:36.467
That preformatting and

144
00:08:36.467 --> 00:08:41.757
the text will wreck your world [LAUGH] if
you are trying to make that as a date.

145
00:08:41.757 --> 00:08:44.590
I'll how you a little fix, but
that's something to think about.

146
00:08:44.590 --> 00:08:46.378
This seems to be a running theme, right?

147
00:08:46.378 --> 00:08:49.810
[LAUGH] Preformatting versus
post formatting, well,

148
00:08:49.810 --> 00:08:53.600
it gets a whole bunch of sideways,
so keep that in mind.

149
00:08:53.600 --> 00:08:56.801
I do have a question about the typing
in dates, we did dashes and slashes,

150
00:08:56.801 --> 00:08:57.587
what about dots?

151
00:08:57.587 --> 00:09:01.380
What if we did 1.1.79,
do I get auto formatting?

152
00:09:01.380 --> 00:09:04.847
Because that was one of those
accepted shorthand formats.

153
00:09:04.847 --> 00:09:05.350
Mm-hm.

154
00:09:05.350 --> 00:09:08.280
So I'm kind of interested,
does it recognize that one as well?

155
00:09:08.280 --> 00:09:11.600
Not that way, no,
it does not see dots, okay?

156
00:09:11.600 --> 00:09:16.301
But we did see it in
the Wikipedia article, so

157
00:09:16.301 --> 00:09:19.778
01.01-2014, nope.

158
00:09:19.778 --> 00:09:23.320
But it was preformatted as a date,
we saw that, right?

159
00:09:23.320 --> 00:09:25.750
So it's not understanding that.

160
00:09:25.750 --> 00:09:29.332
This would be one of those, you'd probably
want to do a custom number format,

161
00:09:29.332 --> 00:09:31.470
if you really,
really wanted to keep it as it.

162
00:09:31.470 --> 00:09:35.618
I probably, that's what I answer for
everything is custom number formats, but

163
00:09:35.618 --> 00:09:37.260
it doesn't understand that.

164
00:09:37.260 --> 00:09:38.750
So that is something to think about.

165
00:09:38.750 --> 00:09:40.760
Now the other thing is that,

166
00:09:40.760 --> 00:09:44.850
here I'm gonna undo those two things,
we said that these are dates.

167
00:09:44.850 --> 00:09:47.330
We know that this cell is formatted,
it's a date and it's a long date.

168
00:09:47.330 --> 00:09:54.730
So if I did that 2001,
what if I typed in 1, 2, 3, 3.

169
00:09:56.870 --> 00:10:00.446
That is May 17th, Sunday, May 17th, 1903.

170
00:10:00.446 --> 00:10:03.444
What is going on there?

171
00:10:03.444 --> 00:10:05.360
Do you know about this there, Justin?

172
00:10:06.450 --> 00:10:10.480
This is why dates and times are so hard
to handle whether through data entry or

173
00:10:10.480 --> 00:10:15.020
programming or, mainly because there's
accepted conventions, or there's

174
00:10:15.020 --> 00:10:19.670
an assumption that, if it looks like this,
then this is how you derive that number.

175
00:10:19.670 --> 00:10:22.948
Technically, computer-wise, all of
these are numbers behind the scenes,

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne demonstrate how to proof and control page layout for printing. They show how to spellcheck a worksheet and the options for ignoring or adding to the dictionary as well as how to use the thesaurus and smart lookup.  They also cover print preview and introduce page layout view to add and modify page elements.
episodes.title: Proof, Print and Page Layout

Justin and Vonne continue discussing page layout. In this episode, they show how to modify page layout elements from the page layout view such as headers and footers, page orientation, and margins. They also go over adding print titles, setting a print area, and controlling page breaks."

to kind of get a bird's eye view,

486
00:27:41.181 --> 00:27:43.020
of where I want these to move.

487
00:27:43.020 --> 00:27:47.386
And I can just move these blue lines,
so I can kind of help move around,

488
00:27:47.386 --> 00:27:49.914
where the Page Breaks are gonna happen.

489
00:27:49.914 --> 00:27:53.693
I love page break preview when it
comes to this and it's a lot easier by

490
00:27:53.693 --> 00:27:56.743
pulling those lines down.
>> And, you know what's kind of

491
00:27:56.743 --> 00:28:01.375
interesting about that UI, right now it
says page 1,2,3,4 the text that displays

492
00:28:01.375 --> 00:28:06.810
for page 1,2,3,4,5 Is size relative
to how much is on that page.

493
00:28:06.810 --> 00:28:10.443
If you actually move that,
are text size changes.

494
00:28:10.443 --> 00:28:11.540
>> Let me look at that.

495
00:28:11.540 --> 00:28:12.130
>> Yep.

496
00:28:14.030 --> 00:28:16.150
>> I don't think I've ever noticed that.

497
00:28:16.150 --> 00:28:18.777
>> So we'll give you a relative magnitude

498
00:28:18.777 --> 00:28:21.330
[CROSSTALK] of how much is on each page.

499
00:28:21.330 --> 00:28:23.066
So if you can just match those sizes,

500
00:28:23.066 --> 00:28:26.740
you don't have to worry about
getting the lines exactly right.

501
00:28:26.740 --> 00:28:28.655
It would compromise.
>> I don't think I've ever noticed that.

502
00:28:28.655 --> 00:28:31.645
[LAUGH] That's really cool, thanks Justin.

503
00:28:31.645 --> 00:28:34.340
[LAUGH] Good job.

504
00:28:34.340 --> 00:28:38.510
So yeah, these are great ways to go
ahead and change how your pages break.

505
00:28:38.510 --> 00:28:41.790
The thing is sometimes,
you just get it all sorts of wrong.

506
00:28:41.790 --> 00:28:44.080
Can I just go back to the way
it did it automatically?

507
00:28:44.080 --> 00:28:48.450
You go to breaks and
then you can just reset all of them.

508
00:28:48.450 --> 00:28:52.310
You could also remove a single one,
like if I wanted to,

509
00:28:52.310 --> 00:28:54.280
but I like to just reset them all, and

510
00:28:54.280 --> 00:28:58.920
then it just goes back to the way you
can automatically do your page breaks.

511
00:28:58.920 --> 00:29:01.320
That can be really, really nice to have.

512
00:29:01.320 --> 00:29:07.010
So, like the page breaks, I guess
the last thing that I wanted to show you,

513
00:29:07.010 --> 00:29:10.910
I'm gonna go back over to my normal view,
is print areas,

514
00:29:10.910 --> 00:29:13.600
I will tell you, I don't like print areas.

515
00:29:13.600 --> 00:29:17.180
I don't know why,
I just never really got in the hang of it.

516
00:29:18.560 --> 00:29:23.020
What a print area means, is that you're
designating an area to become the only

517
00:29:23.020 --> 00:29:24.140
thing that prints on the sheet.

518
00:29:25.510 --> 00:29:31.010
When I come back to here, notice that I
have some options of the active sheets,

519
00:29:31.010 --> 00:29:34.360
or I can do the entire work if I want to,
or I can do a selection.

520
00:29:36.160 --> 00:29:38.820
Let's do the selection really quickly,
I know we're about out of time.

521
00:29:38.820 --> 00:29:41.580
So let me just do this,
just stay with me for

522
00:29:41.580 --> 00:29:45.730
a little bit longer, cuz I don't wanna
do it part three with five minutes.

523
00:29:45.730 --> 00:29:49.990
So I come here, I only want this part
to be printed, I just make a selection,

524
00:29:49.990 --> 00:29:51.970
do the print.

525
00:29:51.970 --> 00:29:54.530
Notice that it's not
doing that by default,

526
00:29:54.530 --> 00:29:58.350
you gotta change what
you want to selection.

527
00:29:58.350 --> 00:30:01.590
Perfect, that's exactly what I wanted,
I only want that to be printed.

528
00:30:02.730 --> 00:30:08.160
But I can see, like if you're always
going to just be printing this part out,

529
00:30:08.160 --> 00:30:11.930
just this one section,
you can make this one as a print area.

530
00:30:11.930 --> 00:30:16.370
So you select it, you come over to the
Print Layout, and you go to Print Area.

531
00:30:16.370 --> 00:30:19.980
And you set it, when you set the print
area, I'm gonna click off of it.

532
00:30:19.980 --> 00:30:24.710
Do you see this kind of gray
box-looking thing right there?

533
00:30:24.710 --> 00:30:29.630
That's indicating your print area,
it also becomes a named range.

534
00:30:30.760 --> 00:30:32.070
Keep all this in mind for just a second.

535
00:30:32.070 --> 00:30:36.590
When I go to print, it says print
active sheets, but what do I see here,

536
00:30:36.590 --> 00:30:39.210
that's not the whole sheet here, is it?

537
00:30:39.210 --> 00:30:40.910
No, and that's the thing that bothers me,

538
00:30:40.910 --> 00:30:45.960
is because when you set a print area, it
will always over ride the sheet setting.

539
00:30:45.960 --> 00:30:48.750
It will always be print area, and

540
00:30:48.750 --> 00:30:52.570
you notice you don't have an option
in here for print area, do you?

541
00:30:52.570 --> 00:30:55.740
You're like, so why isn't it working,
why can't I get the active sheets?

542
00:30:55.740 --> 00:30:59.180
And if this has ever thrown you off,
cuz it saves with the file,

543
00:30:59.180 --> 00:31:01.650
you're like I just want the whole sheet.

544
00:31:01.650 --> 00:31:05.430
Somebody has print areas
on that particular file.

545
00:31:05.430 --> 00:31:12.070
So knowing what they are is one thing,
seeing the lines, how do I select it?

546
00:31:12.070 --> 00:31:14.170
So notice it says print area.

547
00:31:14.170 --> 00:31:16.450
So that's where it's a named range, but

548
00:31:16.450 --> 00:31:19.050
the biggest thing is like I
want you to print the sheet.

549
00:31:19.050 --> 00:31:23.290
Stop overwriting it cuz it always will,
you come up to print area and

550
00:31:23.290 --> 00:31:24.460
you clear it.

551
00:31:24.460 --> 00:31:28.560
And once you clear it now when I print,
the whole page,

552
00:31:28.560 --> 00:31:31.220
sorry, sheet will print out.

553
00:31:31.220 --> 00:31:34.090
That's why I've never like print areas
because I don't like the overwriting.

554
00:31:34.090 --> 00:31:38.100
If I want something, I'll either hide
columns, hide rows, make a selection and

555
00:31:38.100 --> 00:31:39.290
say, print selection to me.

556
00:31:39.290 --> 00:31:40.617
I have way more control, and

557
00:31:40.617 --> 00:31:43.370
it doesn't throw me off.
>> That was actually enough.

558
00:31:43.370 --> 00:31:45.460
Follow up question about print areas.

559
00:31:45.460 --> 00:31:48.040
Do they have to be contiguous?

560
00:31:48.040 --> 00:31:51.970
As far, so can I select and select
individual pieces, and then set a print

561
00:31:51.970 --> 00:31:54.470
area based on those disparate selections?

562
00:31:54.470 --> 00:31:55.960
>> Like, here?
>> Yep.

563
00:31:55.960 --> 00:31:58.295
>> So now I have these two things.

564
00:31:58.295 --> 00:32:02.088
[CROSSTALK] It will print that and there.
>> But

565
00:32:02.088 --> 00:32:04.080
a bunch of empty space.
>> Yeah.

566
00:32:04.080 --> 00:32:05.479
That's not good.
>> It's a second sheet.

567
00:32:06.760 --> 00:32:09.030
>> Naw, cuz what I was thinking is,

568
00:32:09.030 --> 00:32:10.990
maybe it's an alternative to show and
hide, right?

569
00:32:10.990 --> 00:32:15.910
And that would make sense, but
if you select non-contiguous

570
00:32:15.910 --> 00:32:20.207
blocks it goes well there is a space here,
we're just not gonna show you what it is.

571
00:32:20.207 --> 00:32:21.490
[LAUGH] And it does weird things.
>> And

572
00:32:21.490 --> 00:32:24.550
that might be a reason why you want to do
it, because I'm always gonna print this

573
00:32:24.550 --> 00:32:26.650
and this, but
I want it on page one and page two.

574
00:32:26.650 --> 00:32:30.120
Great, go ahead and send it, okay, And
if you wanted to include more of it,

575
00:32:30.120 --> 00:32:30.800
that's fine.

576
00:32:30.800 --> 00:32:35.040
But to me it just, I don't like,
that's why I don't like.

577
00:32:35.040 --> 00:32:40.370
It overrides my sheet print option,

578
00:32:40.370 --> 00:32:44.380
and that's why I've just never
gotten on board with Print Areas.

579
00:32:44.380 --> 00:32:46.620
So, that's just personal preference.

580
00:32:46.620 --> 00:32:50.540
You can do it if you want, and
it can hopefully save you a lot of time.

581
00:32:50.540 --> 00:32:53.750
But, do you have another question, Justin?
>> I do have one more question.

582
00:32:53.750 --> 00:32:56.640
So, and
maybe this has been on another episode.

583
00:32:56.640 --> 00:32:59.970
But we talked about those row headers,
right, that are printed on each sheet.

584
00:32:59.970 --> 00:33:02.770
There's a check box right up
there that says Headings.

585
00:33:02.770 --> 00:33:07.400
Are those the same thing or am I mistaken?
>> Those are the headings

586
00:33:07.400 --> 00:33:08.540
of like the a, b, c.

587
00:33:08.540 --> 00:33:14.680
If I print those, now it's going to print
out columns a, b, row one, two, three.

588
00:33:14.680 --> 00:33:17.710
So it's the actual Excel Headings.

589
00:33:17.710 --> 00:33:22.640
These are print titles, so
that's the repeating row that I

590
00:33:22.640 --> 00:33:26.980
want to repeat at the top, or repeating
column that I want to print on every page.

591
00:33:26.980 --> 00:33:31.645
So, it's a, you were close but not really.

592
00:33:31.645 --> 00:33:32.360
[LAUGH]
>> Well,

593
00:33:32.360 --> 00:33:35.380
I can see how you would mix that up,
I would probably check that box and

594
00:33:35.380 --> 00:33:38.460
go print, and
no I want this to repeat, right?

595
00:33:38.460 --> 00:33:43.360
I'm essentially getting the grid layout,
for the Excel sheet on every page.

596
00:33:43.360 --> 00:33:46.960
But I want the first row and
the left most column, or

597
00:33:46.960 --> 00:33:49.560
whatever it may be,
to print out on every sheet.

598
00:33:49.560 --> 00:33:51.247
So I just had to ask that question.

599
00:33:51.247 --> 00:33:55.880
Vonne, you've definitely illustrated some,
a few got you's that could be frustrating.

600
00:33:55.880 --> 00:33:59.210
But now that you've shown us, well,
we're not gonna be frustrated anymore.

601
00:33:59.210 --> 00:34:03.340
There was a lot going on ther, but,
incredibly important when you are thinking

602
00:34:03.340 --> 00:34:06.950
about, I need to send this as PDF,
or an email, or print this out.

603
00:34:06.950 --> 00:34:10.320
You know, actually go a board meeting or
something, I don't know.

604
00:34:10.320 --> 00:34:13.090
But, thank you so much and
thank you for joining us.

605
00:34:13.090 --> 00:34:14.180
We are going to get heck out of here.

606
00:34:14.180 --> 00:34:17.950
So, signing off for OfficeProTV, I'm your
host Justin Dennison and I'm Vonne Smith.

607
00:34:17.950 --> 00:34:18.530
And we'll see you next time.

608
00:34:18.530 --> 00:34:25.600
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne finish up the series by demonstrating how to manage workbooks and worksheets. Here they show you how to rename worksheet tabs, change tab color, rearrange worksheets, create new and delete worksheets, and copy/hide/move worksheets. They also show how to control view options such as freeze panes, split view, new windows, and arranging windows.
episodes.title: Manage Worksheets and Workbooks
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.947 --> 00:00:16.064
Greetings everyone and welcome back to
another exciting episode of OfficePro TV.

3
00:00:16.064 --> 00:00:17.750
I'm your host Justin Dennison,

4
00:00:17.750 --> 00:00:21.309
and we're continuing on with our
Excel 2016 essentials for Mac.

5
00:00:21.309 --> 00:00:25.609
And well, we're going to be looking

6
00:00:25.609 --> 00:00:29.461
those two words that I tend to always
mix them up, and you may as well.

7
00:00:29.461 --> 00:00:33.020
But luckily we have someone
that's going to make sure we get

8
00:00:33.020 --> 00:00:37.015
everything we need with workbooks and
worksheets and well, managing.

9
00:00:37.015 --> 00:00:38.798
Ms. Vonne Smith,
how are you doing today, Vonne?

10
00:00:38.798 --> 00:00:40.485
>> I feel like you're setting me up.

11
00:00:40.485 --> 00:00:44.030
[LAUGH] Everything, ooh,
I don't know about that one.

12

>> All right, so as a programmer,
I tend to over promise and under deliver.

13
00:00:47.440 --> 00:00:49.820
So we're just gonna have to go with it,
right?

14
00:00:49.820 --> 00:00:50.551
So-
>> [LAUGH] Yes,

15
00:00:50.551 --> 00:00:53.360
no, but you are right,
I mess them up all the time, too.

16
00:00:53.360 --> 00:00:58.800
But we are going to be managing our
worksheets within our workbooks.

17
00:00:58.800 --> 00:01:03.050
So we'll cover all of that, yeah,
I guess we will cover everything here.

18
00:01:03.050 --> 00:01:08.009
And this is a fun episode, I always
like this one cuz this is the one where

19
00:01:08.009 --> 00:01:12.737
I show people just very kind of,
I would consider the basic things.

20
00:01:12.737 --> 00:01:15.380
They're like, ooh, that's how you do that.

21
00:01:15.380 --> 00:01:18.485
And they get really excited, and
then they go and color code everything,

22
00:01:18.485 --> 00:01:20.505
which is perfect because
that's what I do too.

23
00:01:20.505 --> 00:01:24.325
So we're just gonna be working
with the worksheet tabs.

24
00:01:24.325 --> 00:01:26.130
Whew, that is a mouthful.

25
00:01:26.130 --> 00:01:29.940
And you know, why don't we just
get started, and have something so

00:01:29.940 --> 00:01:32.000
I can demonstrate while I talk.

00:01:32.000 --> 00:01:35.910
So, things out the bottom, let's go
ahead and jump down into my workbook.

28
00:01:35.910 --> 00:01:39.300
I have my file called managing,
or no, what does that say?

29
00:01:39.300 --> 00:01:41.680
Managed worksheets, okay.

30
00:01:41.680 --> 00:01:46.190
And we've got this, you've seen probably
the same information on all these files,

00:01:46.190 --> 00:01:50.143
I just rename them differently for
different shows, or I guess episodes.

32
00:01:50.143 --> 00:01:56.453
We have worksheet 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6.

33
00:01:56.453 --> 00:01:58.974
We know how to navigate them
because we talked about that.

34
00:01:58.974 --> 00:02:00.159
We just click on them, right?

35
00:02:00.159 --> 00:02:02.852
And we click, and we click, and we go.

36
00:02:02.852 --> 00:02:05.918
I don't know what's on sheet 2,
or sheet 1, or

sheet 3, that is not a very good name.

38
00:02:08.820 --> 00:02:12.280
And you saw in the Christmas cats

00:02:12.280 --> 00:02:14.810
They actually had different colors,

40
00:02:14.810 --> 00:02:16.557
Yeah, that's what we're gonna do.

41
00:02:16.557 --> 00:02:17.660
We're gonna manage our worksheets.

42
00:02:18.770 --> 00:02:21.740
First thing, renaming, all right?

43
00:02:21.740 --> 00:02:26.850
Justin and I are just talking about
this before the show started, and

44
00:02:26.850 --> 00:02:29.530
you found out the shortcuts, didn't you?

45
00:02:29.530 --> 00:02:33.504
>> Yeah, yeah, I found out that
you can double-click them.

46
00:02:33.504 --> 00:02:37.489
And yeah, I've been right clicking and
renaming and just, I don't know,

47
00:02:37.489 --> 00:02:41.613
it's those small gains in productivity
that are wins, but you also feel bad.

48
00:02:41.613 --> 00:02:44.145
Cuz you're like,
man why wasn't I doing it this way before?

49
00:02:44.145 --> 00:02:47.426
>> [LAUGH] I feel the same way,
maybe not about the worksheet tabs, but

50
00:02:47.426 --> 00:02:48.491
I've done that too.

51
00:02:48.491 --> 00:02:50.950
Where you're just like [NOISE], years,

52
00:02:50.950 --> 00:02:55.156

way that was taking so much longer.

53
00:02:55.156 --> 00:03:00.016
But we're all creatures of habit, we get

54
00:03:00.016 --> 00:03:01.760

55
00:03:01.760 --> 00:03:04.160
And yeah, it changes your world,

56
00:03:04.160 --> 00:03:06.700
but it also kinda rocks your
world a little bit too.

57
00:03:06.700 --> 00:03:09.810
So yeah, double-clicking,
a lot of people find this by mistake.

58
00:03:09.810 --> 00:03:13.420
Because they single click to select but
then they double-click and

60
00:03:15.280 --> 00:03:18.060
You just got into the renaming

61
00:03:18.060 --> 00:03:22.130
And you know that you're renaming because,
I'll just single click and

63
00:03:25.990 --> 00:03:30.300

00:03:30.300 --> 00:03:31.870

65
00:03:31.870 --> 00:03:35.390
So while it's all selected,
if I wanted to, you know what?

66
00:03:35.390 --> 00:03:37.840
Justin, you're going to be sheet two,

67
00:03:37.840 --> 00:03:39.920
So then I go ahead and type in Justin,

I always just tell people to hit enter,

71
00:03:47.730 --> 00:03:49.800
So if I double click on sheet three,

72

73
00:03:54.700 --> 00:03:56.400
You can also just click off of that and

00:03:56.400 --> 00:03:59.580

commits those changes as well.

75
00:03:59.580 --> 00:04:02.940
Few things though on your sheet names.

76
00:04:02.940 --> 00:04:09.472
If I take this here on Sheet 5,
if you double click,

77
00:04:09.472 --> 00:04:13.341
what if I try to do, Cats Meow.

78
00:04:13.341 --> 00:04:17.916
And, wait, I forgot, [LAUGH] dashes

79
00:04:17.916 --> 00:04:22.569
you know what, it's not the dash,
it's the, whoops, double click,

80
00:04:22.569 --> 00:04:26.029
let me just,
I just use my arrow keys to get the slash.

81
00:04:26.029 --> 00:04:27.980
That's what I was trying to do.

82

00:04:32.060 --> 00:04:35.082

asterisks, or the angled brackets.

85
00:04:39.490 --> 00:04:44.930
Because I do know that those are specific
commands or syntaxes that I believe

86
00:04:44.930 --> 00:04:50.810
are in certain maybe probably vba or
some type of coding that is associated.

87
00:04:50.810 --> 00:04:52.510
I just can't do that.

88
00:04:52.510 --> 00:04:54.080
So you have that with file names and

89
00:04:54.080 --> 00:04:58.050
things in certain platform that
these are just reserved characters.

90
00:04:58.050 --> 00:05:02.680

91
00:05:02.680 --> 00:05:04.670
Can I put curly brace curly brace?

00:05:04.670 --> 00:05:08.040
Because coming from a different
background, I'm like well,

93
00:05:08.040 --> 00:05:10.010

as well.

94
00:05:11.010 --> 00:05:12.712

95
00:05:12.712 --> 00:05:16.015
>> [LAUGH] I was like,
